characters: INT. LOS ANGELES COURTHOUSE, HALLWAY. MORNING
INT. BROADWAY REHEARSAL SPACE, NEW YORK. DAY
INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE'S APARTMENT. SEVERAL DAYS
EXT. ALLEY BEHIND HOLLYWOOD BOULEVARD. DAY
EXT. FLATBUSH AVENUE, PARK SLOPE, BROOKLYN. DAY
YOU NEED TO WASH YOUR FACE BEFORE
INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE'S APARTMENT. DAY
EXT. NICOLE'S NEW PLACE. ECHO PARK, LA. NIGHT
INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE'S APARTMENT, NEW YORK. DAY
INT. PIZZERIA, PARK SLOPE, BROOKLYN. DAY
EXT. PASADENA RESIDENTIAL STREETS, LA, LATE DAY
EXT. RENTAL CAR AREA, LAX AIRPORT. DAY
INT. CONFERENCE ROOM, CENTURY CITY, LA. DAY

dialogues.speaker: INT. THEATER. MANHATTAN. DAY
dialogues.text: Nicole, early 30's, appears out of the dark.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She makes people feel comfortable about even embarrassing things. We remain CLOSE on her face in shadow. She’s very still and very serious.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She really listens when someone is talking...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FLATBUSH AVENUE, PARK SLOPE, BROOKLYN. DAY
dialogues.text: Her coming out of a subway. A young “funny” ASPCA solicitor stops her.

dialogues.speaker: SOLICITOR
dialogues.text: Hey, you look like you care about animals?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I do. --.sometimes she listens TOO much, for too long-- She’s a good citizen. The kid launches into his pitch. She listens intently and starts writing down her phone number.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She always knows the right thing to do when it comes to difficult family shit.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE'S APARTMENT. DAY
dialogues.text: Charlie is sulking. A hand holds out a phone.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Just call him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Call him. No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with real empathy) Call him. He reluctantly grabs the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I get stuck in my ways and she knows when to push me and when to leave me alone. INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE’S APARTMENT. ANOTHER DAY She cuts their son, (8 years old) Henry’s hair. We see Charlie sweeping up.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She cuts all our hair. Cuts Charlie’s hair. We see the kid sweeping up. Cuts her own in the mirror. Charlie and the kid play in the background. She sweeps up her own hair.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She’s always inexplicably brewing a cup of tea that she doesn’t drink.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE'S APARTMENT. SEVERAL DAYS
dialogues.text: A kettle whistles. STILL LIFES of mugs of tea on window sills, bookshelves, Henry’s toy shelf, on the floor... All the kitchen cabinets are open. Charlie closing drawers, picking up shoes. Charlie hitting his head on th corner of an open cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And it’s not easy for her to put away a sock, or close a cabinet, or do a dish, but she tries for me. A framed PHOTO of Nicole, Sandra (her mom) and Cassie (he sister) standing in the front lawn of a Hollywood home. Nicole is pretending to step on the reclining dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicole grew up in LA around actors and directors and movies and TV and is very close to her mother, Sandra, and, Cassie, her sister. INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE’S APARTMENT. ANOTHER DAY Charlie rips open a present. It’s a trumpet.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Nicole gives great presents. She is a mother who plays -- really plays -- she never steps off playing or says it’s too much (and it must be too much some of the time).

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PROSPECT PARK, BROOKLYN. DAY
dialogues.text: She and Henry play in the park with Star Wars figures. Th kid makes high pitched sounds for the fights.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Arrrh, waaa, urgh...

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE HENRY
dialogues.text: Arrgh-- No, he’s dead.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: My guy is dead?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: He’s dead but you can use this guy.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (taking that guy) She’s competitive. Arrrhhggg-- INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE’S APARTMENT. ANOTHER DAY Nicole, Charlie and Henry are playing Monopoly.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Goddammit! I was just IN jail! Henry and Charlie look at each other and laugh.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Do NOT laugh at me. I’m serious. Do NOT LAUGH AT ME!  INT. HENRY’S ROOM. ANOTHER NIGHT Nicole is reading to Henry in bed. She’s falling asleep while reading, but still managing to read.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She’s a great dancer. Infectious. She makes me wish I could dance.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THEATER. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Nicole putting on a song and getting people to dance at a cast party.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She always says when she doesn’t know something or hasn’t read a book or seen a film or a play (whereas I fake it or say something like, “I haven’t seen it in a while.”) She keeps the fridge over-full. No one is ever hungry in our house. She can drive a stick. INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE’S KITCHEN. ANOTHER DAY Charlie’s trying to open a jar of pickles. He struggles. He knocks it on a table. Grabs a dish towel and tries it that way. No luck.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She’s amazing at opening jars because of her strong arms, which I’ve always found very sexy. INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE’S APARTMENT. ANOTHER DAY On TV, a younger Nicole (acting in a movie) is part of a raucous college party.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE IN THE MOVIE
dialogues.text: You might as well get what you paid for! She grabs her shirt and lifts it-- We PAUSE mid-lift before it comes off.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She’s brave. After that movie, All Over The Girl, she could have stayed in LA and been a movie star, but she gave that up to do theater with me in New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're back to the first image of her face in half-shadow. Suddenly she walks forward and into a spotlight.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My crazy ideas are her favorite things to figure out how to execute. She walks across the floor and climbs (scales like a rock face) the body of a male actor.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Try it crawling but also standing. We see that she’s on a stage, rehearsing for a play.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She’s my favorite actress.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THEATER. SAME DAY
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Charlie, early 30’s, in deep thought. A warm yellow glow on his face.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What I love about Charlie... Charlie is undaunted. He never lets other people’s opinions or any set-backs keep him from what he wants to do.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PIZZERIA, PARK SLOPE, BROOKLYN. DAY
dialogues.text: Charlie eats sloppily with Henry at a pizza place. He suddenly stands up and walks around to Henry’s side. He asks Henry to raise his arms. He lifts Henry’s sweater up over his arms and turns it around to face the right way.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Charlie eats like he’s trying to get it over with and like there won’t be enough food for everyone. A sandwich is to be strangled while devoured. But he’s incredibly neat and I rely on him to keep things in order. INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE’S APARTMENT. LATE DAY Nicole is reading in a room. All the lights go out. She looks up. Charlie is at the switch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He’s energy conscious. He turns them back on.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He doesn’t look in the mirror too often. He cries easily in movies.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MOVIE THEATER. DAY
dialogues.text: He and Henry exit a movie theater. Both of them are crying.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I cried four times.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Me too. I wonder if it was the same four.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (V.O)
dialogues.text: He is very self-sufficient -- he can darn a sock and cook himself dinner and iron a shirt. INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE’S KITCHEN. EVE He’s cooking - it’s elaborate. There are a lot of pots, a lot of steam. Henry is “helping.”

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (holding up a knife) The peppers are cut!

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He rarely gets defeated (which I feel like I always do). INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE’S APARTMENT. ANOTHER DAY Nicole is raging about something.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Charlie takes all of my moods steadily, he doesn’t give in to them or make me feel bad about them. He’s a great dresser, he never looks embarrassing which is hard for a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie is serving in a tennis game.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He’s very competitive. He double faults.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (to himself) Goddammit Charlie! Get it together. INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE’S BEDROOM. NIGHT Henry walks into their bedroom and taps Charlie on the shoulder until he wakes up.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (whispers) I had a bad dream.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He loves being a dad, he loves all the things you’re supposed to hate, like the tantrums, the waking up at night. INT. HENRY’S ROOM. SAME He puts Henry back to sleep. Henry doesn’t want to sleep. They compromise with Charlie sleeping on the floor. Then Henry climbing down and sleeping with him on the floor. Then Charlie slipping out and getting into the bed. Then the kid getting into the bed with him.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s almost annoying how much he likes it, but then it’s mostly nice.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SUBWAY/PLATFORM. DAY
dialogues.text: He and Henry reading on the subway. The doors close. The train lurches forward. Charlie looks up suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He disappears into his own world. He and Henry are alike in that way.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What’s “shit?”

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That was our stop!

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He can tell people they have food in their teeth or on their face in a way that doesn’t make them feel bad. Nicole, from across a table picks something from between her teeth, she looks back up at Charlie who is off-camera and smiles. It’s still there. She starts digging for it again.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Charlie is self-made -- his parents -- I only met them once -- but he told me there was a lot of alcohol and some violence in his childhood. Henry plays on the floor. Charlie leads a meeting with hi set decorator and Nicole and the stage manager around a b table. They reference a model of the stage set.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He moved to New York from Indiana with no safety net and now he’s more a New Yorker than any New Yorker.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THEATER. ANOTHER DAY
dialogues.text: Charlie is passing out coffees to all the actors and crew members of their theater at the beginning of a rehearsal. He’s gotten everyone’s drink right, and bought them all himself.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He’s brilliant at creating family out of whoever is around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made sure they used the With the theatre company he right almond milk-- cast a spell that made everyone feel included. No one, not even an intern was unimportant. He could remember all the inside jokes.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (handing an intern a coffee) And where do YOU go when it’s windy?!

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG INTERN
dialogues.text: (laughing, flattered, remembering) Oh yeah, that was funny!

dialogues.speaker: INT. THEATER. PREVIOUS DAY
dialogues.text: We RETURN to the close-up of Charlie. He sits in the back of an empty theater taking notes, the small yellow readin light illuminating his face. He watches Nicole, in rehearsal, climb up onto the actor as she did earlier.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Let’s stop there. Nicole, up almost atop the actor’s head, turns to him wit a look that asks, “Was that OK?” Charlie nods. INT. MEDIATOR’S OFFICE. DAY CLOSE on a sheet of paper: We can see written everything just heard.

dialogues.speaker: MEDIATOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who wants to start? Nicole, no make-up, in a baggy sweatshirt and jeans, sits in a chair, not saying a word, staring at a piece of pape in her lap.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I’m not going to read this out loud.

dialogues.speaker: MEDIATOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I don’t like what I wrote.  10. We see now that she and Charlie are sitting in two adjace chairs in an office on the Upper West Side. A male mediator, 50's, in a sweater vest wearing too many rings, tightly cross-legged, facing them.

dialogues.speaker: MEDIATOR
dialogues.text: As we mediate your separation and eventual divorce, things can become quite contentious, so I like to begin with a note of positivity. For the people I work with to remember why they got married in the first place. And so, that as you come apart, you’re reminded that this is a person you had great feeling for and maybe still do in many ways--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (holding up his phone) I‘1l read mine. I like what I wrote.

dialogues.speaker: MEDIATOR
dialogues.text: For it to really work, you both have to read--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (folding up her paper) I’m not going to.

dialogues.speaker: MEDIATOR CHARLIE
dialogues.text: OK-- She always says I can’t write. But I think mine is pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: MEDIATOR
dialogues.text: Nicole, maybe you'll change your mind once you hear Charlie's.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (looking at him now) I don’t want to hear Charlie’s.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We promised to listen.

dialogues.speaker: MEDIATOR
dialogues.text: That’s right, that’s the very first step in this process. Nicole stands up, suddenly furious.  11.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Well, I think I’1l go if you two are just going to sit around and suck each other’s dicks! A hubbub of protests then:

dialogues.speaker: INT. THEATER. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Audience members watch, rapt. Nicole is on-stage in a red dress. A black and white video of her face projected on either side of her. On stage, she delivers her lines in a almost life-less way while the video Nicole is very animated and emotional. Charlie sits in the back of the theatre--she can’t see hi face, but she knows where he is. She continues speaking, looking into the audience when several bodies approach her, turn her to her side and car her off like a stiff rolled-up rug. Charlie sees her looking and is sad and disturbed and sto writing his notes for a moment. Behind her, a portal opens up, the stage is awash in red light and the company members carry her through the door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. RESTAURANT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Closing night party. The whole company is there celebrating, this is clearly their spot. There’s a piano, and names are pulled from a bowl and people take turns singing. Investors mingle as well, notable for the disobedient air of people who shouldn’t be “downtown.” A woman, 30’s, Mary Ann, also the stage manager (we saw h earlier in rehearsals), sits in a booth with the costume designer, Donna, 40’s. She looks over at Charlie ina booth in the corner, surrounded by members of the troupe. He works on a beer and makes more notes in a book.

dialogues.speaker: MARY ANN
dialogues.text: Do you think I can go over there now? Donna, turns and we SWING OVER to: Nicole, on the other side of the room at a table flanked by other members of t cast and crew.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Not yet.  12. On Charlie’s end of the room, Frank, an older actor, carries on with Terry, a younger one.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: ...Charlie gave me the note - but it’s really for you: he told me to pick up my cues.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: How is that for me?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Acting is reacting - I’m responding to you and you’re slowing ME down.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR 3
dialogues.text: ..-hey, hello, Frank - it’s closing night, you know, we’re done?!

dialogues.speaker: LIGHTING TECH TERRY
dialogues.text: ...first, no, we're moving (also doing HANDS!) to To The BroadWAY! (doing some HANDS!) The BroadWAY-

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: The Main Stem. They all cheers and laugh.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR 2 FRANK
dialogues.text: ..-but we’ll have to restage .-..it’s still a good note.. it anyway!

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR 1
dialogues.text: .».-and you know Charlie, it’s never done, he never finishes.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR 3
dialogues.text: We NEVER FINISH!

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR 2
dialogues.text: Love you, Charlie. They all laugh, but they’re excited, it’s big. Charlie, still looking at his notes, reaches out and pats the actor’s leg affectionately. Terry, gets up--

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I need a cigarette.  13. --and makes his way across the room passing other company members and snippets of conversation.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (dramatically) ...that’s why it seems wrong to take over for Nicole - the role is hers! And what if her pilot doesn’t go, she’ll come back from LA and want the part back, right?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR 3 BETH
dialogues.text: No, she’s done with it. Something like 100 percent of pilots don’t get picked up.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR 4
dialogues.text: It can’t be 100 percent. There would never be any shows.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR 5 BETH
dialogues.text: No, but statistically, it’s You don’t think Charlie and true. The probability is Nicole will ever get back zero. It’s one of those together? things.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR 3
dialogues.text: (sadly) No, this time it’s really over.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (to herself) Still feels weird...

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR 9 ACTOR 7
dialogues.text: ..-I feel like MY parents It’s always been “Charlie are splitting up. and Nicole.” It just doesn’t sound right any other way.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR 3
dialogues.text: Poor Henry. Terry passes Mary Ann and Donna who still watch Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: MARY ANN
dialogues.text: (re: Charlie) How about now?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I'd wait, honey. Terry arrives at the booth at the other end of the room where Nicole and her group are camped together.  14.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER ACTOR
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) He still giving notes?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: SET DESIGNER
dialogues.text: (to Nicole) You’re lucky, Nic, I wish I was going to LA. You can have space in LA. There’s no SPACE here. Nicole looks across the restaurant and catches Charlie’s eye. He mouths “hi” and she nods. Is it nice?

dialogues.speaker: MARY ANN
dialogues.text: (growing more impatient) Now?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Don’t do it. Frank stands and makes a toast to Charlie and Nicole and the move to Broadway ("The Main Stem”) and how much they’ miss Nicole and then makes it about him returning to Broadway with the young turks. In 1968, he was the young turk.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Winning your first Tony at 27-- which I did--messes with your head. I was just a baby! Elia Kazan came backstage on opening night elbowing Mike Nichols into a corner. Mike, who I later turned down twice, a big regret of mine... During the speech, Mary Ann, the stage manager, suddenly rises (we can see Donna making protestations) and makes h approach to Charlie’s corner, whispering something in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: MARY ANN
dialogues.text: I wanted to make sure that I have all your notes down so I can compile them into the master list for when we move into the new theater... Nicole, clocking this, abruptly stands. Charlie sees her rise and does the same.  15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riding home across the Manhattan Bridge. Nicole sits on the mostly empty bench gazing out the window. Although there are available seats, Charlie stands and leans against the doors. INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE’S APARTMENT. NIGHT She and Charlie enter and relieve a young babysitter who for some reason is buttoning her pants up and looks a little ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: BABYSITTER
dialogues.text: Oh hey, I didn’t expect you guys until late.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: How’s he doing?

dialogues.speaker: BABYSITTER
dialogues.text: Good, good. He went to bed on time, no fuss. I read him some of Cricket in Times Square... (takes them in) God, you guys are so attractive. (hand to mouth) Shit, sorry. I didn’t stop that from being said. Nicole goes back and checks on Henry--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ha! No it’s okay. I’1l pay Hey, thanks! And also the you for the whole time, we travel time to Greenpoint-- decided to come home early. She stumbles on something. It’s his little suitcase, open on the floor--toys crammed into it. He’s sleeping soundly all twisted up in his superhero sheets. He uses a well- worn white bear as a pillow. She fixes his sheets. The Babysitter is gone and Charlie is setting up the couc as his bed. He surveys the room while he reflexively fiddles with a small X-Acto knife on his key chain. We CU QUICKLY between objects (the clicking sound of the knife a soundtrack): Books, a chair, table, lamp, a TV which turns on, painting, photos... Objects from their life together. (Mugs of tea rest beside some of these objects. A book on a table.  16. Nicole retrieves the book and heads back to the bedroom. Charlie’s voice stops her:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s not always going to be like this, it’s going to get better. Nicole nods.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: If you don’t like that mediator, we'll find another one--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah... We might not need a mediator, we'll just split everything anyway, I don’t care--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Me neither-- You can have most of it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: We'll get apartments near Right. each other, make it easier for Henry--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We'll figure it out. We want the same things. Nicole meets Charlie’s eye. He hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: In the meantime, the pilot will be fun for you.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: You don’t think it’s bad, do you?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (hesitates) I don’t ever watch TV so, you know, I can’t tell... Nicole glances over at the TV which is on.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I told Henry I’11l come out to LA in two weeks to see him.  17. Nicole nods. Charlie looks down at his notebook. Looks back up at Nicole.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Nothing. Nicole turns, and then turns back.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I can tell you want to give me a note.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, I don’t... Yeah, I mean, yes I do. But I guess, I guess it doesn’t matter now. You won’t be with the show anymore. It’s stupid.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (knowing him well) You’re not going to be able to go to sleep until you tell me.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Maybe not.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Okay then.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, yes, okay, but just because saying it out loud might help me remember it for later.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: (reading) --okay-- So - there were two things - I thought your posture at the top of scene seven was still too dignified...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: --and then at the end, I could tell that you were pushing for the emotion--  18.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: --you know I can’t cry on stage and I know you don’t like when I fake it, but I thought maybe it would come tonight. But it didn’t... He flips through the notebook. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That’s all I had. Thanks for indulging me.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Goodnight Charlie. She starts crying as soon as she turns away from him. We MOVE with her as she cries through the apartment to their bedroom. She trips briefly on one of her suitcases also lying on the floor open and half-packed. She removes her shoes, but not her clothes, and gets into bed, crying. Fade to Black. A curtain flies open revealing a rich blue sky and swayin palm trees. The light is painfully bright. We hear a female voice lightly singing:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: “This is the day, this is the day...” INT. NICOLE’S CHILDHOOD BEDROOM, LOS ANGELES. MORNING Nicole opens her eyes which are crusted with mascara and tears. Her mother, Sandra, 60’s, violently opens the curtains, loudly closes drawers and doors. We're in LA.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: (singing) “That the Lord has made, that the Lord has made...” Nicole rolls over. Henry, yawning, lies next to her in th bed.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: (singing) “Let us rejoice, let us rejoice. And be glad in it and be glad in it...”  19. This is her childhood bedroom in her mom’s house. There are old magazines (Cosmo, Seventeen, Teen Vogue, Maxim) with photos of Nicole. An MTV Best Kiss award. There is “Teenage Nicole” and “Adult Nicole” all mashed up togethe and both Nicole’s are messy. Nicole presses her face into the pillow.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE HENRY
dialogues.text: Mom... (tired) G-ma summer is for relaxing.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: (to Henry) You can’t make home too nice, otherwise your children will never leave-- Nicole whispers to Henry.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: What do you want to do today?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY NICOLE
dialogues.text: Hang out and relax with you. (nuzzling him) Me too.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: (listening in) No relaxing! Nicole has a hair and make-up test and Henry, we got you into Fairy Camp with the cousins.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I hate Fairy Camp.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Cassie says everyone likes Fairy Camp and I think this is true. Sandra kisses Henry on the head.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Henry, go make your mom some coffee like I taught you--

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Mom, wait till you taste my coffee. Henry walks off, hair sticking up. Sandra fluffs the pillows, retrieving Henry’s white bear.  20.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Do you always sleep together? Even in New York?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: It’s just for now, while we go through this transition. Shit, don’t tell Charlie when he gets here -- he hates co-sleeping. Nicole climbs out of bed. Her pillow is stained with blac eye make-up.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Well, I have to say, I agree with Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Surprise, surprise. Nicole walks toward the bathroom, Sandra behind her--

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA NICOLE
dialogues.text: It’s as if you’ve exploded (looking at her phone) into this room. Jesus, it’s early. --and into the bathroom, her mother follows her inside.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I can do this part alone?

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: That’s fine. I won’t look. Sandra leans against the sink, Nicole shrugs and lets her how can she stop her now?

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: As long as you’re in my house, wake up is at 6:30 AM. And until you know what you want to do, we're going to do what I like to do.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I can’t just go from what Charlie wanted to do to what you want to do. Nicole finishes, flushes and starts washing her hands.  21.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Even though I’m sixty-four and have a dead gay husband, I manage to get up everyday and live my life and feel pretty good about myself so maybe your Mom knows a thing or two. Nicole heads out of the room and down the main staircase. Her mom following her, of course.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA NICOLE
dialogues.text: You know what I would do? (no idea) About what?

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: When Charlie gets here, I would whisk him off to Palm Springs? That’s what your father and I did whenever we hit a speed bump--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE SANDRA
dialogues.text: Didn’t you walk in on Dad And I always regretted blowing the porter in Palm getting so upset about it. Springs?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Charlie and I are getting a divorce, Mom. There’s nothing for us in Palm Springs.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: (suddenly angry)

dialogues.speaker: YOU GO TO SLEEP.
dialogues.text: They both enter the kitchen. Henry has made a giant mess with the coffee, and he’s trying to press down on a Frenc Press coffee maker.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: When Daddy gets here maybe we can all go on the Jaws ride--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE HENRY
dialogues.text: Yeah-- (accommodating) Or I can go once with you and once with Daddy because I wouldn’t mind going twice anyway--  22.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA NICOLE
dialogues.text: (to Henry) No, we'll all go together, Did you know Universal sweetheart. Studios is where I did my first screen test-- Henry presents his mom a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: On the plane, I re-read the pilot as if I were Charlie reading it and I started to think it’s just bad.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: My agent says it’s “one to watch.” She sips her coffee.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (to Henry) This coffee IS good. Thank you. (to Sandra) What if Charlie’s on Broadway with the play I brought him--which I originated and I’m just doing bad TV.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter. Everyone is only impressed when they see someone on TV.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PRODUCER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She’s beautiful. Nicole is standing in front of a camera in a hair/makeup/wardrobe test. She’s barefoot in a nightgown with some kind of red mask being applied to her face. We hear voices (that she can’t) murmuring near the monitor. Nicole holds what looks like a blue, foam football and stares combatively at the camera. Hands enter frame, adjusting her hair, swapping out the masks.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Where’s she been for the past ten years?

dialogues.speaker: MALE PRODUCER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Doing weird theater in New She looks great. York.  23.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Can I say something? No one answers. We hear bits of side-conversations about book club book they’re all reading.

dialogues.speaker: MALE PRODUCER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Downtown shit. I saw one. It rained on stage.

dialogues.speaker: DP, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Plays make me uncomfortable. It was good. Edgy. Directed by her husband. Supposedly very controlling.

dialogues.speaker: DP, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The live aspect-- We’re lucky to have her.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m surprised she said yes. We can thank her divorce.

dialogues.speaker: EFFECTS GUY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Can she move her hand? It’s going to be hard to roto the hair in on the baby around her fingers--

dialogues.speaker: MALE PRODUCER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (aloud to Nicole) Can you move your hand further down the baby?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Like down here?

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Off his head entirely-- I’d need to support his head.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No, no, support the head, of course, just try to do it from the shoulders? She hesitantly slides her hand down the blue football.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Perfect.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I can’t hold a baby like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She’s right, that’s going to look weird. A handsome, bearded and tatted 24.

dialogues.speaker: EFFECTS GUY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Just so you know, we can TOTALLY do it, it’s just going to take time and money and mean less hair. grip, 30's, Pablo, enters frame with a white bounce board, holding it up to her.

dialogues.speaker: GRIP
dialogues.text: So we can see your pretty face. And not ours.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Ha. You should have seen me before the plants invaded.

dialogues.speaker: GRIP
dialogues.text: I say that with respect. I was raised by two mothers.

dialogues.speaker: DP, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (not amused) Can you lower the board please, Pablo? The grip lowers the bounce board then raises it directly front of Nicole’s face, then lowers it, being cute.

dialogues.speaker: GRIP
dialogues.text: Here? How Nicole smiles. A hand removes another.

dialogues.speaker: GRIP
dialogues.text: How about now? Pablo finally places the board

dialogues.speaker: GRIP
dialogues.text: (to the DP off-camera) That better, boss? Someone walks through the shot arm.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (louder) Can I say something? ‘bout here? her mask and applies

dialogues.speaker: MALE PRODUCER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why is there always a flirty grip. in the proper position.

dialogues.speaker: MAKE-UP ARTIST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I can do ANYTHING you want, but we’ll need to have her two hours before call every day we work with the plants-- carrying an enormous plant

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PRODUCER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hold on. (to Nicole) What honey?  25.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: She has to know how to hold a baby. Later after she kills Donny, she becomes this sort of earth mother for the plant community and that won’t make sense if we think she’s a bad mother to her own kid.

dialogues.speaker: MAKE-UP ARTIST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She kills Donny? That’s a secret. We didn’t give the crew those pages.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: You don’t want her to appear unsympathetic this early in the show, do you?

dialogues.speaker: MAKE-UP ARTIST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Does Donny know? She’s right.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Also, why does she kill Donny anyway?

dialogues.speaker: INT./EXT. SOUNDSTAGE. LATER
dialogues.text: Nicole marches across the soundstage, still in the nightgown, now wearing Uggs, followed by the male (Dennis and female (Carol) producers, both 50’s. He wears all denim. She’s in fitted jeans, and a white blazer. There’s also a cadre of hair and make-up and wardrobe people.

dialogues.speaker: MALE PRODUCER
dialogues.text: Must be nice to get out of New York. Our daughter, Mia is at NYU living in a shoe box--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE MALE PRODUCER
dialogues.text: Well, I’m from out here-- She's says it went up toa hundred and four the other day--

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PRODUCER NICOLE
dialogues.text: We're just so excited to (nods ) have you. I’m excited to be here --

dialogues.speaker: MALE PRODUCER
dialogues.text: We're going for an early aughts aesthetic — so having your presence nails that.

dialogues.speaker: MAKE-UP ARTIST
dialogues.text: What signifies early aughts?  26. They go outside, the bright LA light hitting their eyes. Everyone puts on sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PRODUCER
dialogues.text: Into The Girl was on TV--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE FEMALE PRODUCER
dialogues.text: (correcting her) --or streaming or something All Over-- and you are fucking HOT in that movie.

dialogues.speaker: MALE PRODUCER FEMALE PRODUCER
dialogues.text: Carol-- Fuck it, I speak my mind!

dialogues.speaker: MALE PRODUCER
dialogues.text: We're not allowing our son to see it.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PRODUCER
dialogues.text: Because you show your tits.

dialogues.speaker: MALE PRODUCER NICOLE
dialogues.text: Carol-- Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MALE PRODUCER
dialogues.text: This is Carter Mitchum, he’s a futurist at UCLA who’s consulting on all the environmental stuff for the show. Carter, 30’s, has been politely following behind. He reaches forward to shake her hand.

dialogues.speaker: MALE PRODUCER
dialogues.text: You know, so it’s accurate.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER NICOLE
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you. So, is it?

dialogues.speaker: CARTER NICOLE
dialogues.text: What? Accurate?

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: So far none of it. Nicole laughs. She’s handed another nightgown by the wardrobe assistant. “For when you’re on the mother ship.”

dialogues.speaker: MALE PRODUCER
dialogues.text: This pilot WILL go. Get ready to move back to LA!  27.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PRODUCER
dialogues.text: And listen: everything you were saying back there was absolutely right--

dialogues.speaker: MALE PRODUCER FEMALE PRODUCER
dialogues.text: Except no one knows we’re If she’s a bad mom, we'll killing Donny. Including lose the audience. Donny.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Oh...good, you know, I just thought-

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PRODUCER
dialogues.text: Let us know if you’d like to be part of our writer’s room -- I bet you'd be really helpful.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (surprises herself even) Or I could direct? Sorry, maybe that sounds crazy.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PRODUCER
dialogues.text: No, yeah... Do you have a reel?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: No, because I’ve never done it. I mean, I watched my husband do it for years... (quietly) Almost ex-husband? What’s the opposite of fiance?

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PRODUCER
dialogues.text: (taking her in) We'll talk to your agents about it.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: At our theater, I always wanted to direct and Charlie would say something like “The next one!” But he was always the director and there never was a next one. (contradicting herself) But I don’t know, maybe there would have been if we stayed married. You know, I don’t know. Nicole turns away, embarrassed. The Female Producer has been watching her, while the Male Producer is just textin like a motherfucker.  28. INT. NICOLE’S TRAILER Nicole enters the cramped space and realizes the Female Producer is right behind her. Nicole tries to busy herself.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PRODUCER
dialogues.text: (takes out her phone) I’m going to give you a number.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Oh...OK. Is it a therapist? I have a therapist. Well, she’s my mom’s therapist. We share her.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PRODUCER
dialogues.text: She’s a lawyer, she represented me when I left Dennis.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE FEMALE PRODUCER
dialogues.text: (re: the male producer) Since 2013. You and Dennis are divorced?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: And you still work together? That’s nice.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PRODUCER
dialogues.text: Oh, no, he’s a fucking cocksucker. Nora got me half of this project in the settlement.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: We talked about doing it without lawyers.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PRODUCER NICOLE
dialogues.text: You think that, but you My sister made me meet a won't... bunch of them already, I just HATED them.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PRODUCER
dialogues.text: (with certitude) Call Nora. She saved my life.

dialogues.speaker: NORA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I look so schleppy. INT. NORA FANSHAW’S OFFICE. DAY Nora Fanshaw, 40's, looks amazing and elegant. Today she is in tight designer jeans, a YSL blazer, red pumps and full make-up.  29. Nicole, in old jeans and a button-down, sits on a comfortable, stylish couch, a Moroccan rug on the floor-- an office that looks like a suite at a W Hotel. A sheepskin throw, fresh flowers on the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: I had an event at my kid’s school. Nicole grows suddenly self-conscious about what she’s wearing.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Let me get this out of the way, I think you’re a wonderful actress.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: I loved All Over The Girl but the theater stuff too.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE NORA
dialogues.text: (can’t help but be I saw Electra. pleased) You’ve seen the theater stuff?

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: I was in New York last year for my book -- which, remind me to give you a copy -- and my publisher took me.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE NORA
dialogues.text: Oh...great. Thank you. Fantastic. You’re awesome.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (almost apologetically) Charlie directed it.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: I know. He’s very talented.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: He is. They’re moving it to Broadway. Without me of course.

dialogues.speaker: NORA NICOLE
dialogues.text: He was lucky to have you. While I’m making a show about a plant invasion.  30.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: (really asking the question) How are you doing? Having been asked that question at that moment in that wa does something to her. Tears run down Nicole’s cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Oh, honey. Nora kicks off her shoes and tucks them under her feet. She rises, grabs a box of tissues and curls up next to Nicole on the couch. Nicole takes a tissue and she and Nora meet eyes. It feel intimate and safe.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: You take some breaths. And while you do, I’m going to tell you about myself. She texts something to someone and then very deliberately puts her phone down on the table. Nora puts her hand on Nicole’s leg. She talks to her like a good girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: If you should choose to hire me, I will work tirelessly for you and am always available by phone or text, EXCEPT when I’m with my kids. I insist on doing drop-off and pick-up at school every day.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (likes this) Oh, I understand. An assistant enters with a tray that has green tea and cookies. Nicole starts eating the cookies, Nora does not.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: I’ve been through this myself so I know how it feels.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE NORA
dialogues.text: (hopeful) Yes. I have a kid from my You do? ex who was a narcissistic artist and verbally abusive. I’m now with a great boyfriend, who lives in Malibu.  31.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Oh, good. (hesitates) But Charlie’s not terrible.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: No, of course not, but they ravish you with attention in the beginning and then once we have babies, we become the mom and they get sick of us. Nicole nods.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Where do you want live now, doll?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (takes a breath) Well, I’m here now, obviously, and I don’t know if this show will be picked up, but... it feels like home... it is home. It’s the only home I’ve known without Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: You want to stay here. Nicole likes hearing this affirmation, but then hesitates

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Charlie won’t want to do that. He hates LA.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: We're interested in what YOU want to do. Sounds to me like you did your time in New York. He can do some time here, no?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (nods ) He always said we would, but we never did.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: How old is your son?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Henry is eight. He likes LA, but I don’t know if it’s fair to him...  32.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: It sounds like a wonderful childhood to me: the first half New York and the second half in LA.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (to herself) The second half... Nicole processes this.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: I want you to listen to me, what you’re doing is an act of HOPE. Do you understand that?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE NORA
dialogues.text: (suddenly meaning it) You're saying, I want Yes. something better for myself.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE NORA
dialogues.text: I do. And this, right now, is the worst time. It will only get better. Wasn’t it Tom Petty who said the waiting is the hardest part?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE NORA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I represented his wife in their divorce, I got her half of that song.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Oh, I don’t want money or anything, he doesn’t have money anyway, he puts it all back into the theater-- I used to think he gave TOO much away. I just want it to be over.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Of course you do. But we can do both.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I just worry... You know we weren't going to even use lawyers so...I don’t want to be too aggressive. I’d like to stay friends.  33.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, we’ll do it as gently as possible. (beat) Now, can you tell me a little bit more about what’s going on? Because part of what we’re going to do together is tell your STORY. Nicole wipes her eyes for the millionth time. She stands and grabs a tissue from the table. She takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: It’s difficult to articulate. Sorry. It’s like I know why I’m doing this but I don’t know too. It’s not as simple as not being in love anymore.

dialogues.speaker: NORA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I understand. Why don’t you start at the beginning, wherever that is for you. And Nicole begins. As she talks she finds her voice and gains momentum and she starts to feel better, the tears start to dry up and she becomes more powerful, more herself.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Well, I was engaged to Ben, you know, and living in LA and I felt like “Yes, I want to make movies and marry Ben” - Jesus I was only nineteen or twenty, I’ve never felt older in my whole life - But if I was honest with myself, there was a small part of me that felt dead, or dead-ish, but you tell yourself “no one is perfect, no relationship is perfect.” (realizing) Boy, this tea is delicious.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Isn’t it? It’s the Manuka honey.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Anyway, you were asking about Charlie. So yes, so I was happy with Ben, but aware of the deadness. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And then I went to New York to meet a director for a space movie, but one where they take space seriously. Sex trafficking in space. It was political, or they wanted us to think it was. It was actually just fulfilling the same need certain fucked up porn does. Anyway, while I was there, the producer invited me to a play. It was in someone’s living room with all the lights on and like nothing I'd ever seen before. A strange, surreal dystopian story. So well acted and one of the actors was this big shaggy bear who played all his lines looking directly at me which I knew couldn't be really the case, but it felt that way, and of course later I learned that it was. (also realizing) The cookies are really great too.

dialogues.speaker: NORA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I‘’1l give you some to take home.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Afterwards, I was introduced to the cast and this bear turned out to also be the director. He didn’t really know who I was - or he did, or he figured it out later - and that was it. He started talking to me. And I talked back - and the dead part wasn’t dead, it was just in a coma. And it was better than sex, the talking. Although the sex was also like the talking... everything is like everything ina relationship, do you find that? ... We spent the whole night and next day together, and I just... never left. And to be honest, all the problems were there in the beginning, too. I just went along with him in his life because it felt so damn good to feel myself alive. In the beginning I was the actress, the star, so that felt like something. People came to see me, at first. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But then the farther away I got from that and the more the theatre company got acclaim, I had less and less weight. I became “Who?” “Oh you remember, that actress who was in that thing that time.” And he was the draw. And that would have been fine, but...I got smaller. I realized that I didn’t really ever come alive for myself, I was just feeding his aliveness. He was so smart and creative, it didn’t matter. I would tell him things at home, in private, and then they would work their way into public conversation, into his work and for a while that felt like enough. I was just so flattered that someone like him would find an idea of mine worth using or a comment of mine worth repeating. And then I got pregnant. And I thought “having a baby will be ours, really ours, and it will also really be mine” and he was so excited. And it was nice for a while. But kids... they belong to themselves. Like the instant they leave your body, it’s just a process of going away from you. And I didn’t belong to myself. It was stupid stuff and big stuff-- All of the furniture in our house was his taste. I wasn’t even sure what my taste was anymore because I'd never been asked to use it. I didn’t even pick our apartment, I just moved into his. I made noises about wanting to move back to LA, but it came to nothing. We’d come here on holidays because he liked my family, but whenever I suggested we do a year or something, he’d put me off. It would be so weird if he had turned to me and said “And what do you want to do today?” I watched that long documentary about George Harrison and I thought “just own it, own it like George Harrison's wife. Being a wife and mother is enough.” And then I realized I couldn’t remember her name. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So this pilot came along, and it shot in LA and it paid so much and it was like there was a little life- line thrown to me “Here is a bit of earth that’s yours.” And I was embarrassed about it in front of him, but also, it felt like “this is who I am, this is what I’m worth and it’s stupid, but at least it’s mine.” And if he had taken me in a big hug and said “Baby, I’m so excited for your adventure and of course I want you to have your own piece of earth” then we might not be getting divorced. But he made fun of it. And was jealous, like he is. BUT then he realized about the money and told me I could funnel it back into the theatre company. And that’s when I realized that he truly didn’t see me. He didn’t see me as something separate from him. And I asked him to say my phone number. And he didn’t know it. So I left. Nora wipes a ink-stained tear from Nicole’s cheek and hug her.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (realizing she forgot to include) I think Charlie also slept with Mary Ann, the stage manager.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: (fierce) That fucking asshole. INT. SANDRA’S HOUSE, LOS ANGELES. EVENING Cassie husband, Sam and their kids, Jules and Molly, play Monopoly with Henry in the den. Henry has trouble reading the Chance card. Sam helps him with it.

dialogues.speaker: JULES
dialogues.text: You should buy everything.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: But I want to keep my money.  37. INT. SANDRA’S KITCHEN. SAME CLOSE on a manilla envelope with Charlie’s name on it and Nora’s firm’s address in the corner. Cassie, 30’s, Nicole and Sandra are preparing. They’re all drinking wine and drinking it too fast.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: So, Cassie, you’re going to hand him the envelope--

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: Why do I have to do it?

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Because Nicole is very good at getting people to do things for her--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE SANDRA
dialogues.text: That’s not what this is-- I wiped her butt until she was nine years old. She's very seductive that way.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: No. Mom. Legally I can’t be the one who serves him.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA CASSIE
dialogues.text: But still this is true what (nervous now) I’m saying. Do I have to actually hand him the envelope?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Yes, but I’m going to tell him in advance that they’re divorce papers. Nora says it doesn’t have to be so formal. (suddenly nervous) Where’s Henry? Nicole finishes what’s in her glass and pours herself mor

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: He’s in the living room playing with Jules and Molly.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Let’s get them upstairs. So, I’1l tell Charlie what’s happening and Cassie, you can then hand him the envelope--  38.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE SANDRA
dialogues.text: OK, I just get nervous-- (nervously) Can you un-serve?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: What do you mean, like take it back?

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (getting anxious) I think so.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE SANDRA
dialogues.text: You should check. In case we change our minds.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I’m not going to change my mind.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE SANDRA
dialogues.text: I know, but maybe just to Or we all just feel too bad know in case I do something for him. wrong--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Now you're both just making ME feel bad about it, OK.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE SANDRA
dialogues.text: Sorry... Sorry. I’m We all are. And we LOVE nervous. Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (with more power now) You have to STOP loving him, Mom. You can’t be his friend anymore.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Charlie and I have our own relationship independent of your marriage just like I’m friends with Cassie’s ex, Jeff--

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: (news to her) Are you still seeing Jeff?!

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: (shrugs) An occasional lunch.  39.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE SANDRA
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you! He still wants his camera I‘1l play Sandra is back by the way.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (getting emotional, but staying strong) Listen, nothing can be independent of our marriage right now. I can’t believe I have to explain this to you. Just be on MY side,

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: And stop seeing JEFF!

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Cassie, you’re the server.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: Just let me practice a few times. I was never a good auditioner.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: You wanted it too badly.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: It’s not an audition.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA CASSIE
dialogues.text: Charlie. It’s just my palms are so perspired.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Sweetie, you’re blotting the envelope. Maybe Nicole should play you.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: Did you really just say that???

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: We don’t need to practice it. It’s not a performance! working on opening a bottle of wine.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Did we finish the other one already?  40.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: (with dead certainty) Oh, yeah. Outside, a car door closes, they all jump. Cassie even screams. Nicole snaps into action.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: OK, let me get it. You both go in the other room. Cassie, make sure Henry goes upstairs with Jules and Molly.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: Happening now. Cassie and Sandra disperse. Nicole goes to the door. Sandra reappears from another entrance.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Mom!

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: I’m getting my wine. She grabs her glass and scurries away as Cassie reenters.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: Henry’s pooping in the bathroom downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Can we transfer him to the upstairs one?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: I think it’s mid-poop.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: OK, grab him when he comes out. (Cassie nods and starts to leave) Cassie!

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (re: Nora’s legal document ) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m putting the envelope here by the toaster.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: Copy you. Cassie hurries out of the room. The back door opens, Charlie enters in a whirl. He kisses Nicole on the lips, heading into a spare bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hey-- Where’s Henry?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: He’s pooping.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hi Henry! He dumps his bags on the floor. She watches through the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Does this couch still open? He reappears, squeezing past her into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (excited) I got off the plane to a text-- But don’t tell anyone yet, it’s still a secret.

dialogues.speaker: OK--
dialogues.text: He goes straight to the refrigerator, passing the manila envelope next to the toaster. He turns to Nicole, unable to contain his excitement.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I won a MacArthur grant.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Oh, Charlie, that’s so great. Congratulations! She hugs him, truly happy for him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: Thanks. (so pleased) I’ll say it because you can’t, it’s the genius grant. You’re a genius.  42.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: (bashful, but beaming) I’m really happy for you. Well... You deserve it--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s yours too. We did all of this together.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Well, thank you, but it’s yours, Charlie, enjoy it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m starving-- Charlie removes a roasted chicken from the refrigerator.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s good money, and they parse it out over five years, but it means I can keep everyone in the theater company employed, pay my credit card debt and--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (eyes on the envelope) It’s so great.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Of course I went instantly to, “it’s all down hill from here.” Now my first Broadway play HAS to fail--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: We just started rehearsals You always don’t know at again...I don’t know... this point and then it gets there--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Do I? Cause I don’t remember.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I know, but it’s true. It’1l be great.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (smiles) OK. I hope you’re right. Everyone says, Hi.  43.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Tell them Hi. I miss everyone.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: Well, you’ll see them when A MacArthur, Broadway, it’s you come back-- so exciting. Congratulations, Charlie. He picks at the chicken with his hands, licking his fingers. Nicole takes a breath, wanting to acknowledge th envelope sitting now to Charlie’s right and all that’s about to happen.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Which bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What? Is he pooping? He starts He knocks

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Oh...downstairs. off. She follows him into the other room.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Your mom home?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, she’s upstairs-- on the bathroom door.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hey, how’s it going?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Nothing yet.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s me.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I just got here.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I brought you something.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yay. Mom is giving me a present too.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: For pooping.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh... (pause) I love you.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I love you. Charlie reenters the kitchen. Nicole trailing.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t think we should reward him for pooping anymore.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I know, but he holds it in, It’s its own reward. it’s getting on a week... Sandra pokes her head in.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Hey there, Charlie-bird.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (smiling) G-ma! Sandra kisses him on the lips. He lifts her up. Nicole watches impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Don’t, I’m so heavy!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You’re light as a feather.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, God, I’m so HUGE! You didn’t respond to my last email!

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Your emails are so articulate, I get intimidated!  45.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE SANDRA
dialogues.text: Mom, can you help with-- Now, I’m going to lift You! She wraps her arms around him and he pretends to be lifte

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA NICOLE
dialogues.text: What? Upstairs--

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Oh... (to Charlie) I’m going to go write you back now. Sandra reluctantly leaves as Cassie enters.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hey, Charlie. Cassie, I like your haircut.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: (disarmed) Oh, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mom!

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Henry’s calling you, Nicole!

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I hear him! What's going on, Henry?!

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Can you have Mom come?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He wants you-- Nicole and Cassie look at one another.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (mouths ) Wait for me-- Charlie continues to eat (and mangle) his chicken. Cassie stands in front of him awkwardly. She collects her things holds a pie tin, on top of a script. She’s red faced and blushing, and shaking from nerves.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What kind of pie is that?  46.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: (for some reason that stumped her) It’s... (long pause, as if trying to recall a line ina play) Pecan.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Did you make it?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. No! It’s store bought. You know Joan’s on Third?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, that’s good, right?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: What? The store? Yeah! Jules and Molly love it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (re: her nerves) Are you OK?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: Yes. I’m just HOT.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I‘1l pour you some water. (he does) Nicole says you're doing a play?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: (happy to be asked) I think you’d like it! It’s a great unproduced play by this really interesting British writer.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: So you do an English accent?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s more Northern England.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, what does that sound like?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: Ya want a cup of tea, do ya?  47.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, right. Good. (doing an OK English accent) Oh, thank you, missus. What is-- Charlie’s gaze goes down to the counter. The legal envelope lies there. Cassie sees him seeing this.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: (still trying British) It’s a manilla envelope, love. (shakes her head) Can I start over?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It has my name on it. He picks it up. She lunges forward and violently grabs it out of his hands. She hesitates and then formally hands i back to him.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus, sorry. You’re served. Sorry. Nicole reenters. She sees Charlie holding the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (to Cassie) What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: Nothing. I don’t know. I can’t lie. You’re being served. You guys are getting divorced. I don’t know. I’m sorry. She runs out of the room. Nicole looks at Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I was going to warn you. So it didn’t become a thing. Charlie stares at the envelope. And then:

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.  48.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (eyes on the envelope) I feel like I’m in a dream.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: We don’t have a marriage anymore. Charlie looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I know you don’t want the disruption, but you don’t want to be married. Not really.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (holding up the envelope) But I don’t want THIS.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Well, what did you expect was going to happen?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know... I guess I didn’t think it through. But I thought we agreed-- Nicole gets out a bottle of whiskey and pours two drinks. She places one on the counter in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: We weren’t going to use I want a... I don’t know, lawyers. I’m trying to say this as undramatically as possible. I want an ENTIRELY different kind of life.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Let’s wait until you finish this pilot and come back to New York and... Let’s figure it out there, at home. Together.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Nora is known for being We don’t need to do this really fair- with envelopes and...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (holding up the envelope) This is Nora?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Yeah. She’s great. I feel like we could be friends with her.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why do I feel like that won’t happen...

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s a formality and you (suddenly) don’t have to respond right Why...why did Cassie have a away. pie?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: The pie was hers. The pie wasn’t part of it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I mean, what would the pie have to do with anything?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: I don’t know, it somehow Sorry. The pie was just a makes it worse. pie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: So, what... What do I do?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: You get a lawyer too. INT. NICOLE’S ROOM AT SANDRA’S Charlie and Nicole lie in bed together on either side of Henry. Charlie is reading Stuart Little. They get to the end. Both Charlie and Nicole wipe tears from their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I forgot it ended that way.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Wow. Stuart really over- reacted, didn’t you think?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: He was upset about his boat. Charlie kisses Henry on the head.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Dad, you go away-- Mom, you stay--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: But Daddy, just got here--  50.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s OK. I love you.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (picking up his Dad’s disappointment) But you can come back and wake me up and read to me later, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: Charlie gets up and walks outside the door. We STAY with Nicole and Henry.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (whispers) Will you come sleep in my bed later?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (whispering) Yes. We CUT TO Charlie standing outside the door and for the first time shift to HIS perspective. He hears their whispers. A door squeak grabs Charlie’s attention. Sandra peeks out from her room.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: (whispers, shaking her fists) Hang in there, Charlie-bird.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (whispers) Thanks G-ma. Sandra shuts her door. He looks at the family photos on the hallway wall. Sandra younger on a TV show, being directed by Roberto, a handsome curly haired man with big glasses. Nicole and Cassie as kids. A framed image from a New York Times article on Charlie a Nicole. They pose, looking great, standing apart on the stage of the theater. Titled: Scenes From A Marriage. Nicole comes back out. She sees Charlie looking at the photo. She hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: He’s in a Mommy phase right now.  51.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s OK. They both head down the stairs. Nicole sways for a second and clutches a bannister. Charlie takes her arm.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Sorry, I think I drank too much wine--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: I can imagine. Stressful And didn’t eat dinner-- time.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Ha, yeah... I hope Henry didn’t notice.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m sure he didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Now that I’m a parent I realize my parents were probably drunk all the time with me.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sorry again.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Where are you staying?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, um...I hadn’t...I guess I’ll... He puts on his jacket, and leaves the room--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: There’s a new hotel over on Highland that’s supposedly not too expensive and pretty nice.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh...OK...I1’11 check it out.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Again, that’s great about the MacArthur. Charlie reappears clutching his bag.  52.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Thanks. They half-hug strangely, he holding his bag in one hand, she holding the legal envelope. He heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (turning hopefully) Yeah? Nicole hands him the envelope with the divorce papers.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Thanks. Charlie flips off all the lights in the room. Leaving Nicole in darkness.

dialogues.speaker: A VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Fuck. INT. JAY MAROTTA’S LAW OFFICE. DAY Charlie sits across from a lawyer, 50's, a strong, husky silver-haired man in a suit. This is Jay Marotta. The office is nothing like Nora’s -- sleek, corporate, tough. There are photos of Jay playing sports. An associate, 30's, Ted, a younger jock, sits at an adjacent table, taking notes.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: (to the associate) She’s being represented by Nora. Ted nods, knowingly.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: She’s supposedly very fair?

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: Here’s the fact Jack: I charge 950 dollars an hour, Ted is 400, so if you have a stupid question, call Ted.  53. Ted smiles at Charlie. Charlie looks sick.

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: To start we’ll need a twenty-five thousand dollar retainer--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s more than I can--

dialogues.speaker: TED JAY SILVERMAN
dialogues.text: And all your financials. Which runs anywhere from ten We'll need to do a forensic to twenty thousand dollars. accounting.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (sweating) But if we can all agree right away, it shouldn’t get too bad, right?

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: (not responding) You were married here, in LA?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE JAY SILVERMAN
dialogues.text: Yes, because her mom and And your son was born out sister are out here and I’m here? not close with my family and so we just did it here...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes, because again her family was out here and I’m not--

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: So you got married here, your kid was born here and she served you here?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. But we LIVED in New York. (pause) Why? Is there a problem?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: We're going to have to reshape the narrative.

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: If you’re serious about having your child in New York, this is what I would suggest, you take the kid, did you say his name is Fred--  54.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: Henry. --Henry? Why did I think Fred.

dialogues.speaker: TED JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: I have a kid named Fred. --you take Henry to New York with you right now. Then we file an action in New York. Make it a New York case--

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: We need to make an argument that you’re a New York based family.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: Well, we ARE. Otherwise, you’1ll probably never see your kid outside of LA again.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (shocked) Really? No.

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: It’s very difficult to convince the courts to MOVE a kid. As soon as you let your wife and child leave New York, you made life very difficult for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but as I said, we are a New York family, that’s just a fact. She’s here temporarily.

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: (leading question) Then why do you think she served you out here? Jay and the associate exchange a meaningful glance.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t...know. But, Henry wants to go back to New York, he tells me--

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: Don’t quote your kid. He’s just telling you what you want to hear. Trust me, he’s telling her the opposite. Jay looks back at the papers.  55.

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: What’s Exit Goat?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Exit Ghost. It’s the name of my theater company.

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: You're a director?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: Theater director, yeah. Anything I've seen?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. What have you seen? Silence.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Our production of Electra is moving to Broadway which is exciting--

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: We have to make sure that money is protected.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I mean, it’s theater, so it’s not a lot of money. I basically put whatever money I make back in the theater.

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: I wonder-- (looks at Ted) Do WE ask for support?

dialogues.speaker: TED CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Interesting-- From Nicole? I’m not going to do that--

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: Does your wife’s family have money?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Her mother has some from her TV career and her father died--

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA TED
dialogues.text: We could say we don’t want In that instance, her mother her mother to see the kid, could pay your legal fees draw HER into the case. too.  56.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (can’t believe his ears) No. I’m very close to her mom. Nicole's family has been my family-

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: That’s going to change and I suggest you get used to that. (to Ted) We should hire a private investigator--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: Really? I mean...REALLY? We need to look for ways we can show she’s a bad mother.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: But she’s not. Your wife do drugs or anything? Coke?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Not in any real way--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (hesitates) She was addicted to Tums for a while. Jay stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It wasn’t nothing. She was up to a tube a day.

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: Have you noticed anyone following

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: Keep an eye out. California’s a no-fault state so even if you’re fucking around it wouldn’t matter, but, it doesn’t look good-- (stands) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You need to be prepared for the fact that Nora’s going to portray you as a neglectful, absent, father.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: But I’m not--

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: You live in New York, consumed with your work, she and the kid are out here, struggling. Nora will use that strategy, I’m sure of it.

dialogues.text: She’s not going to LIE.

dialogues.text: Listen, if we start from a place of reasonable and they start from a place of crazy when we settle, we'll be somewhere between reasonable and crazy.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Which is STILL crazy.

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: Half of crazy is crazy.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: You know what people say, criminal lawyers see bad people at their best, divorce lawyers see good people at their worst.

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: You’11 end up hating me and Ted before it’s all over just because of what we represent in your life.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m sure you’re right. Charlie looks like he’1ll pass out.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE JAY SILVERMAN
dialogues.text: Maybe I didn’t explain this well. We're friendly, we're fine, we’re just trying to figure this out-- So, tell me the story again, you came out to see your kid and she served you? What a bitch.  58.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: She’s not a bitch...thanks, but this isn’t...we’re doing it a different way. And I can’t even close afford this... I’ve got to get back to New York. I havea Broadway play in rehearsals-- Charlie stands. Fade to Black.
