dialogues.text: Actors are mingling, stretching, in a mostly white room i midtown. Different color tape on the floor indicates the set. Various conversations are going on at once including Frank telling another anecdote from his younger days.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK BETH
dialogues.text: She was Rosalind and I was Do you think it’s OK that Jaques. Nobody knew her I’m doing the laughing fit then -- that way. Nicole did it more like -- (she laughs strangely) I’m doing it-- (laughs her way) And I don’t want to imitate her--

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR 3
dialogues.text: You’re making it your own.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK BETH
dialogues.text: Complete unknown. And I was I just so appreciate that the hot shit you know, young Charlie gave me this and very sexy with this opportunity. Or maybe I great head of hair. should thank Nicole.

dialogues.text: I heard Nicole’s pilot went to series so she’s staying in LA.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR 2

dialogues.text: Is Charlie moving there too?

dialogues.speaker: BETH ACTOR
dialogues.text: Not Charlie. He won’t abandon us.  59.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: And you can’t do theater in LA. They all laugh.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR 5
dialogues.text: Charlie said she and Henry are coming back to New York once she finishes filming her show.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR 1
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t be so sure.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR 5 ACTOR 2
dialogues.text: She was never going to stay She was probably planning in New York. That was this move all along. obvious.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR 5 ACTOR
dialogues.text: When she sees an Well, LA is nice. The opportunity, believe me, she space. takes it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: And you know it’s “The Park” and all that, and Joey Papp was directing, and she just glided on stage... we were cats in heat.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR 3
dialogues.text: Charlie HATES LA. All of their attention eventually drifts toward Frank for the big finish.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Miss future four time Oscar winner sucking my... The door swings open and Charlie enters. He’s immediately swarmed by the costume designer and props guy who is showing him different items to approve. Charlie puts his things down on a white folding table.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Nobody come too close, I think I got Donna’s cold.

dialogues.text: Sorry Charlie. Terry and other actors approach him.  60.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Just a heads up, I’m waiting for a Skype call from Henry so I might have to step out-- Everyone very understandingly says “Of course.” “Say Hi from us” etc. Frank puts his arm around Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What you’re going through now is going to be horrible. BUT it will be over.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE FRANK
dialogues.text: Thanks, Frank. Another thing.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Fuck as many people as you can right now. Women, men... The Costume Designer, Donna, holds up a brown suit, hat, goggles and white gauze and a small Frankenstein outfit.

dialogues.speaker: COSTUME DESIGNER FRANK
dialogues.text: You might need help wrapping Take what I said seriously. some of the gauze, it needs to stay tight.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, that’s my Halloween costume. And the Frankenstein is for Henry. All the actors surround him, approving of the outfits. “Aww!” “So cute!” “Frankenstein and the Invisible Man!”

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE COSTUME DESIGNER
dialogues.text: He’s coming here this I made it more James Whale weekend and we're going to than Kenneth Branagh. trick or treat in the Slope and whatever--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, over--  61. Charlie and Mary Ann duck into the hallway. The crew clocks this and makes knowing eye contact with one anothe

dialogues.text: (pleased) --from the original layout Where'd you find it? of the Broadway theater--

dialogues.speaker: MARY ANN
dialogues.text: The library. Duh.

dialogues.text: Ha!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (pause) Mary Ann, it’s too hard now...I just can’t be with anyone right now.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Just make sure everything doesn’t go to hell here. I’m relying on you, OK?

dialogues.speaker: MARY ANN CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Fine. Thanks.  62. He kisses her on the head. She flushes, rebuffed.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE MARY ANN
dialogues.text: Hold on, let me-- I wish you'd accept generosity better.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (hesitates after this remark and answers the phone) Hello? Charlie pushes open the fire exit doors--

dialogues.text: Is this Charlie Barber?

dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.text: Hi, this is Nora Fanshaw, I represent your wife, Nicole Barber.

dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: NORA

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: I’m calling because we haven't received a response to our filing. The set designer, Agnes, opens the door to the stairwell and holds up two photos of stools. Charlie points at one of them. The designer nods.  63.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’ve been rehearsing this play and flying back and forth to

dialogues.speaker: NORA

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Nicole said there was no rush. He points at the rotary. She nods gratefully and hurries back inside.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: It’s been more than thirty days since you were served. By law you’re meant to respond within thirty days.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NORA
dialogues.text: I didn’t like the first It says that very clearly on lawyer I met. the document you were given. Did you read it?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: But I thought that’s just what it says...we weren’t going to even do it with lawyers-- Charlie absent-mindedly fiddles with the X-Acto knife on his key chain, opening and closing it. Frank pokes his head in.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Charlie, I’m thinking I shouldn’t tuck in the shirt?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE FRANK
dialogues.text: (holding up a finger to --it keeps coming out during say “hold on”) the love scene-- Nicole said I could take my time--

dialogues.text: And we've let you take your time...

dialogues.text: What love scene? When I hug Beth.  64.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You don’t hug Beth.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It’s something I’m trying.

dialogues.speaker: NORA CHARLIE
dialogues.text: If you don’t file your (to Frank) response we’re going to file You can’t just tuck it in a request for default tighter or get Donna to judgement against you. safety pin it?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (admitting) I also have a thing about tucking in things-- Charlie indicates for Frank to come forward. He tucks it in for him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK NORA
dialogues.text: It’s a hold-over from Charlie? childhood. Insecurities about my figure.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: A default judgement. What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: We'll be able to lay claim to whatever we want.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Whatever you want of what?

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Your apartment, your things--well, everything you own.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: She and I already discussed this, we don’t own that much stuff, she can have pretty much whatever she--  65.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: And it means, we’1ll set the number for child support at its highest level and claim full custody of your child...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (alarmed) Full custody? I mean, that’s not even-- Charlie opens an Emergency Exit door and emerges into--

dialogues.speaker: TIMES SQUARE
dialogues.text: Chaotic city SOUNDS and vibrating video screens. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: This is what the law says.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Nicole’s not going to do that. I mean...she won’t.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: No, Charlie, I represent Nicole and she’s aware of everything I’m saying to you.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I just spoke to her this morning.

dialogues.speaker: NORA

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: You need to get a lawyer and respond immediately. Nicole wants to do this amicably but you’re leaving us no other option, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: INT. RENTAL CAR. DAY
dialogues.text: Charlie drives, fiddling with the air conditioning to no apparent success. He looks uncomfortable and hot. The sun suddenly blinds him through the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (squinting) Ugh, I can’t see.. (pause) And I’m still driving. EXT. SANDRA’S HOUSE, WEST HOLLYWOOD, LOS ANGELES, DAY Henry comes running out. He wears shorts and high socks. Charlie opens his arms but doesn’t get a hug as Henry is to other things.

dialogues.text: It did. Sock pants!  67.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Can I talk to you--

dialogues.speaker: HENRY NICOLE
dialogues.text: Why don’t we ever do a It’s almost noon. treasure hunt?

dialogues.text: (aside to Henry) We got to get going--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE HENRY
dialogues.text: (to Nicole) No talking alone. Can I talk to you fora minute? Henry, can you wait a minute--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Just one bit of talking alone and then I’1l be right there-- He walks Nicole over away from the car and Henry.

dialogues.text: I got a call from your lawyer. She said you’d take everything and custody and everything if I didn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That’s how lawyers talk-- Yeah, but she’s saying things I don’t think you mean--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: It’s better if we just let the lawyers do this--  68.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We said we'd figure this out together. Henry starts running back to the house.

dialogues.text: Henry, we need to get going--

dialogues.text: Have you gotten a lawyer I don’t want to go now. yet?

dialogues.text: Come on, Henry, I’m in a rush-- (to Nicole) And I looked Nora up. She’s fancy. We...you can’t afford her.

dialogues.text: I’m going to be rich!

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE

dialogues.text: (glares at Nicole) He’s not going to the dentist.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE HENRY
dialogues.text: I’m trying to help-- I’m staying here. Henry grabs hold of his Mom.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: OK--
dialogues.text: Charlie gently takes Henry’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Come on-- Henry yanks it back. Charlie pulls again on Henry who is clutching his Mom.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: Henry-- You have a booster? This tug of war feels ridiculous and Charlie lets go.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I have a booster. Nicole looks at the car-seat in the back of the car.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: It’s not in.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: What’s not in? The seat. It’s not connected. Charlie leans in. The car-seat isn’t connected to anything. Charlie and Nicole, both crouched closely together in the back seat, share a small laugh.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I asked the rental company to install it.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I think they can’t for liability reasons--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: Do you know how these things- Let me do it--  70. Henry itches his nose as he watches his parents struggle with the booster seat.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: No, you have to--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Here, you have dig--

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Why “fuck?”

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: You OK?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Something’s sharp--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: There should be a clip thing, a thing to clip on to.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Ow, fuck. Charlie gets out, he’s sweating and his hand is bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Can’t I stay with Mom?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No--

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s my time with you. I just flew three thousand miles.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to-- Henry, get in the fucking car! Henry laughs uncomfortably and then reluctantly climbs in

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (defeated) I’m sorry, but Jesus, get in the fucking car.

dialogues.text: Charlie drives. the back.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: He sucks on his hand which is bleeding looks at all the billboards on the strip. Henry sits in How do you spell Lego Bionicles?  71.

dialogues.text: That’s two words. What does Lego start with?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY

dialogues.text: Don’t you want to learn it?

dialogues.text: No, it’s on the box anyway. L.

dialogues.text: Then what?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. E. You know, everyone at the theater says Hi.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: A “ggg” sound. Are you excited for Halloween?

dialogues.text: Then what?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: An “O” sound.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Are you excited for Halloween?

dialogues.text: I brought both our costumes.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: But we agreed, I had Donna make you a Frankenstein.

dialogues.text: Are you sure, maybe just look at it? It’s awesome. We’1ll be Frankenstein and the Invisible Man!

dialogues.text: Technically, the The cousins are also going Frankenstein costs more when to be ninjas. you factor in Donna’s time and the materials--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (frustrated) But Henry, we went through all this trouble-- (catching himself) OK, whatever you want...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie lowers the window and stretches his arm out to pu the button to get the ticket, but he’s not pulled in clos enough. He has to open the door, unbuckle himself, and step out to push it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wide white space flanked by windows. Charlie, still sucking on his hand, carries two travel bags and he and Henry, having checked in, head toward the elevator bank.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE HENRY
dialogues.text: (in the middle of a I’ve been here. previous conversation) .+--and so I’m not comfortable leaving the bags in a car where I’ve given the key to someone I don’t know--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s an office building so you've been to places like this before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie approaches the receptionist.  73.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I remember those fish.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: A lot of fish look the same. The receptionist looks up.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Can I help you--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: I’m Charlie Barber, I have a (to the kid) one thirty with Dan Cohen. Oh, hi. Where’s your little man?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I don’t have it this time. I keep my skeletons at my mom's. Charlie looks at Henry strangely and back at the receptionist. She scrolls on her computer and frowns.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: OK... Oh, OK... I’m sorry, we tried to reach you, Mr. Cohen wanted me to apologize. He can’t see you because apparently your wife already met with him on the 7th of August about representation...

dialogues.text: But she hired somebody else, uh, Nora...

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t think she would have done it deliberately.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: You'd be surprised.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Did you go to a lot of offices with your mom?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Not so many. Like eleven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In harsh sunlight, Charlie heads for his parked car, on t phone, pulling a rolling bag and hauling a duffel. Henry trails behind him, carrying Charlie’s lap-top bag and eating a hamburger over a paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I don’t think anyone would have stealed the bags, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (into the phone) I need somebody TODAY. If I don’t respond by tomorrow, she said I could lose custody? I didn’t know who else to call... There’s got to be someone she didn’t meet.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (loud whisper) She'd kill me if she knew we were talking.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE VOICE
dialogues.text: I know. I really appreciate It’s high alert over here. it.  75. INT. SANDRA’S HOUSE, BATHROOM, LOS ANGELES. INTERCUT Sandra, her head in a scarf, and tinted blue glasses on, runs the shower to drown out her conversation and talks i a whisper. She flips through an old address book.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: OK, I have a name for you. Bert Spitz. He was the entertainment lawyer at Roberto’s agency, and for years, he negotiated all of Robbie’s Dynasty and Falcon Crest deals. He kind of got pushed into retirement a few years ago and he went into family law.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (reading a billboard) “They’re out for bl-ode.”

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE HENRY
dialogues.text: It’s a double “O”. What Blo-oode? sound is that?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Blood. You’re getting good at reading.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: “They're out for blood.” Charlie and Henry approach the car in the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: I called him and he can see you today at 4.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Great!

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: And he should be more affordable. Charlie opens the back door and indicates for Henry to go in. Henry drops his burger on the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Oh, shit.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE HENRY
dialogues.text: Thank you G-ma. Thank you. Dad! Sandra now lies on the tile floor looking under the bathroom door to see if someone is listening.  Mom?! 76.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: We never had this conversation, Charlie-bird.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Got it! I love you.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I have to go-- Sandra hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I need a new burger.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Because you made us carry your bags into the restaurant, I dropped it. Charlie picks up the burger and wipes it off.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (handing it back) It’s fine, get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Why did you take me today if you couldn’t hang out with me?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Because I’ve been away and want to see you.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ALLEY BEHIND HOLLYWOOD BOULEVARD. DAY
dialogues.text: A cramped parking lot in the back of an old run-down building on Hollywood Boulevard. Charlie helps Henry out of the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: BERT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Getting a divorce with a kid can be one of the hardest things you'll ever do. It’s like a death without a body.  77. INT. BERT SPITZ’S LAW OFFICE. DAY A man, late 60's, in slacks and a tweed jacket, takes a pill from a container and swallows it with a glass of water. This is Bert Spitz. A grizzled cat wheezes in a corner on a stained pillow.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: I know, personally I’ve been there four different times.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You've been divorced four times?

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: I’ve been married four times. Three divorces. This last one will stick God willing. Charlie nods as Bert sits across from him.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: That’s why I graduated into family law. To help people survive this painful time. (leans forward) Here’s how I see it: If we get bogged down in who did this and that and “I don’t want to pay the two dollars” it’1ll just cost you more money and time and emotional stress, and you'll probably end up with the same result anyway.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE BERT
dialogues.text: Right. I mean, I agree with And I always go with the that philosophy. She does truth wherever that takes too, I’m sure. us. Most people in this business make up the truth to get to where they need to go.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: You’re just transactions to them. I like to think of you as people.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh. OK. Good.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: And not just you, her too.  Yes. 78.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE BERT
dialogues.text: It can be an ugly process. But I believe it also doesn’t have to be terrible.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m glad to hear you say that. Um, I’d love to keep expenses down as much as possible.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Of course you do. I charge 450 an hour and I’1l1 need a ten thousand dollar retainer to start.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Maybe this is a stupid question, but is there any way to do this on a budget?

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: This is the budget version.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (swallows ) I’ll see if I can get an advance on the Broadway transfer...

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: And keep in mind, you'll have to pay for her lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh... I didn’t... What?

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Or at least part of her. It doesn’t make sense, does it? The reason you’re doing this is because you love your kid and in doing so you’re draining money from your kid’s education.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It seems ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Oh, it is. Bert shuffles through the papers in front of him.  79.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: We'll have to respond right away. (re: the papers) Your son is in school out here?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Temporarily. We agreed. Her pilot went to series and I wanted to accommodate her as she’s often felt we do things on my terms.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Be a better husband in divorce.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I guess something like that. But we live in New York.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: (putting on his glasses) With your kid in school here, the court may see it otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (alarmed) Will we go to court?

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: No no no, we don’t want to go to court, the California courts are a disaster -- it’s just how we have to think about it. (looks back at the papers) I’m not sure these are my glasses. (removes them, stands) Where are you living when you're out here?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE BERT
dialogues.text: I’m in a hotel right now-- Hotel doesn’t look good.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: To who?

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: The court.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You just said we weren’t going to go to court.  80.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Of course, of course. We prepare to go to court hoping that we don’t go to court.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: You should get a place in LA. And get a place NEAR her. That will look better for custody reasons.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: She’s in West Hollywood. That’1ll be expensive. I guess I could rent our New York apartment.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Don’t rent it, you need to continue to prove New York residence--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE BERT
dialogues.text: (not sure what he’s And of course getting a going to do) place in LA, doesn’t make it K. look like you all live in New York, does it?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: So... (hesitates) What do I do?

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: I recommend you try to spend as much time with your child as possible. Many people fight to get the time and then they don’t even use it. They just want to win. Bert leaves his office and disappears down a hallway. Charlie follows.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: This shouldn’t be that complicated, right? I mean, we’re a New York family. I think it’s all pretty straight-forward. Right?  81. Charlie finds Bert in a kitchen area. The old cat following them. Bert opens an old fridge and takes out some of kind of meat and rice in a tupperware container.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: I hope so, yes. I see no reason-- you both love your son, you respect each other--why this shouldn’t be relatively pain-free?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (pleased) Right. Bert gathers plastic silverware from a drawer and heads through another doorway into an outer office/waiting area Charlie hesitates and follows. Henry looks at a magazine on the floor with Bert’s associate, Nell, 30’s.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: (handing Nell his glasses) I think you have my glasses-- She takes off hers and they swap. She nods.

dialogues.speaker: NELL
dialogues.text: That makes sense.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (to Henry) What have you been doing?

dialogues.speaker: NELL HENRY
dialogues.text: We were talking about money. And I was reading this magazine.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (looking) You were reading California Lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Uh uh.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: OK, I’m almost done. Henry pets the old cat.  82.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t expect too much from that cat. Charlie follows Bert back to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: I want you to know that eventually this will all be over and whatever we win or lose, it’ll be the two of you having to figure this out together.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (moved) Thank you. You’re the first person in this process who has spoken to me like a human. Bert, tears in his eyes, hugs Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: You remind me of myself, on my second marriage.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Mommy ! INT. SANDRA’S HOUSE, LOS ANGELES Henry runs in and hugs Nicole. Charlie stands in the doorway, he holds the Frankenstein Halloween costume. The place is decorated warmly for the holiday and delicious- looking food is being prepared by a house-keeper.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Did you have fun with Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: We drove around to offices.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Do you want to try on your ninja costume? It’s on your bed!

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Yeah! Henry runs upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You know I had Donna build him this whole Frankenstein thing with the plugs and --  83.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The cousins are ninjas so he But he and I had decided wanted to do that too. together--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I can’t make him be Frankenstein.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m not asking you to. But maybe you could help me out a little. I‘1l leave the Frankenstein here and maybe you can nudge him in that direction--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I'll try.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What's the...did you dye your hair again? Is that for your show?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: No, this is me. It was this way when I saw you before.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I know, but I didn’t say anything then.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You don’t like it? No, I guess...it’s fine. Is it shorter? I prefer it long, but...

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (laughs bitterly) I’m sorry, it’s just -- absurd.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Is everything OK?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, why? You seem...I don’t know like something is--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Everything’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: Charlie peers over her shoulder again at the warm living room. Nicole stands as a sort of barrier.  84.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: OK, I’m going to check in at the hotel, but should be able to get to you guys by five, five thirty. We'll go trick or treating from there--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Um, we’re going to go to Cassie’s in Pasadena.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: Cassie lives in Pasadena And trick-or-treating with now? the cousins.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, she and Sam moved a couple of months ago.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: OK. I don’t really know Pasadena. I’ll figure it out. What’s the address? I’1l1 text Sam.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And because my mom is Wait until you see MY looking forward to this and costume. Cassie and Sam are--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Are mad--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Mad at who?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: You.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: Cassie and Sam? You can understand that.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: --so I think we should probably do separate Halloweens--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: But if you’re OK with it, then shouldn’t they be OK with it--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Let’s just do it this way Do you not want me there? this time. OK?  85.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (hesitates) No, I’m fine with it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: OK. It’ll be nice for him, he’1l get two Halloweens.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What am I going to do with him for second Halloween? Walk around Sunset Boulevard?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Maybe the hotel has something? Or you can drive to another neighborhood?

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Charlie, wrapped in gauze, in a brown suit sleeps slumped over on the couch. The TV is on. The hat in his lap. A beer and a crinkled candy wrapper from the mini-bar on th coffee table. The doorbell rings. He startles awake. He puts on the hat, checks himself in the mirror, straightens his goggles and gauze and opens the door. Nicole is dressed in a peach suit and her hair in a sort pompadour a la David Bowie. Henry dawdles behind her, in the hallway. His ninja mask is askew and his costume hanging partly off. Charlie, ignoring Nicole, greets Henry.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (muffled by the gauze) OK! Ready for Halloween!

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (re: Charlie’s costume) Wow. Elaborate. Charlie adjusts his goggles.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (to Henry) Sweetheart, don’t forget your jacket. It’s getting colder. Henry passes by both of them and into the room. Charlie parts the gauze over his mouth so he can talk easier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls to Henry) You ready to go back out?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: He has to pee.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: No, I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) He does. She hands Charlie Henry’s backpack.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Some of his men and Bear Bear are in there-- You can keep this Bear Bear because I got another one--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Does he know that there are two Bear Bears? 86.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE HENRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes, it was his idea-- I have LA Bear Bear and New York Bear Bear-- Charlie regards Nicole.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Station to Station?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Let’s Dance. (waving) OK, bye Henry. Have a great Halloween with Daddy. (to Charlie) Have fun. Charlie nods coldly and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (re: the hotel room) This is a nice house. Henry turns his plastic jack o’ lantern over and his candy on the floor. He lies down and starts it. dumps all sorting  87.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (forcing enthusiasm) Go pee and then we’re going back out!

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I’m too tired!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: GO pee and then we’re going to go drive to Halloween! INT. CHARLIE’S RENTAL CAR Charlie, wiping moisture off the windshield, cranes his neck, trying to see out the glass.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE HENRY
dialogues.text: This block looks promising-- I wish Halloween was over.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, it isn’t. (looking for parking) If we were in New York we could be walking.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: But I like that we’re sitting right now. I like to sit.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That’s true, Los Angeles does have sitting going for it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I think that’s why I like Los Angeles better.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE HENRY
dialogues.text: Because you get to sit? And because I like my friends here better.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That’s not true. What about Horatio and Poppy and--

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Horatio doesn’t like me anymore and I don’t like Poppy. Here I have Axel. Axel is hilarious. And my family is here. Besides you.  88.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cars rush by. The Invisible Man and a ninja in a parka hold hands looking for an opening to cross. They dart across the street. They trudge up a steep curvy street behind Sunset. They stand outside a house. They ring and wait. Nobody answers.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Everyone’s asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They approach the convenience store counter. Henry’s mask is coming off at this point.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Say it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Trick or treat. The seventeen year old clerk looks around and hands them some junk. INT. CHARLIE’S RENTAL CAR Charlie drives. Henry is falling asleep in the backseat.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: They both exhaustedly enter. Henry turns his plastic jack o’ lantern over and a couple of things trickle out. Something lands with a thud. Charlie picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Who gave you a lighter?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (holding his fly) I have to pee. Henry goes into the bathroom to pee. Charlie gets a beer.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m going to have to go back to New York on Monday.  89. Henry comes back out.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Did you flush? Henry goes back in and does. Comes back out.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Wash your hands. Henry returns to the bathroom. Charlie hears the water ru and then he reappears.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Did you hear me? I have to go back to New York. Henry gathers some of his toys.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (playing with his men) Aaah, watch out... BSSSHH! “I’m falling.” “I’‘1ll catch you.” BOOOM. “You didn’t catch me.”

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Why aren’t you here more?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I have to work. You know my play is opening on Broadway.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Is it because you don’t want to be near mom?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No-- You know, like we’ve talked about, we’ve decided not to be together no matter where we are. But we both want to be with you.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: But you’re not near me if you’re in New York.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (clarifying) Well, we all still live in New York.  90.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Yeah. But I go to school here.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Just for right now. Like that time we were in Copenhagen for my play. Remember all those kids in buckets?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I like my school here and Mom says we can stay here if we want. Charlie freezes.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What do you mean...She said that?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Yeah. CUT TO: Henry is asleep in the king size bed in Charlie’s room with his bear as a pillow. Charlie turns out the light and adjusts the covers. He watches Henry for a beat and kisses him on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOTEL BALCONY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Charlie steps out onto the small concrete balcony attache to his room. He’s on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Are you moving out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see now: Nicole stands out by a pool on the phone. She’s still dressed as David Bowie. Agents, the ex-husban and wife producers from her show, actors, all in costume, mingle inside and out.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (pause) Did you find a lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes. Henry says you’re moving here???

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Have your lawyer call Nora.  91. Charlie clicks his portable X-Acto knife in and out.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I want to talk about it as us.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Who the fuck is “us?”

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Let’s just get in a room, YOU and ME, that’s what we always said we'd do.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: My lawyers wouldn’t let me It’s not up to them. It’s sign anything. up to us. It’s OUR divorce.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: They say I could later sue them for malpractice.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (frustrated and growing angry) What am I walking into?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: What are you walking into?!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes! What the fuck is going on?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I read your fucking emails, CHARLIE. I read them all.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: When? I don’t know. Recently!

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You are a FUCKING LIAR. You -.. Shit. fucked Mary Ann.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (weakly) It was after I was sleeping on the couch. Some guests glance over at Nicole who is now shouting.  92.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: And all this bullshit about working on us or whatever, you know what-- I HAVE been working, I’ve BEEN DOING THE WORK. ALONE.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: How did you read my emails?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I HACKED INTO YOUR ACCOUNT I think that’s illegal. YOU DUMB FUCK.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: About a week ago. So don’t How do you even know how to give me this shit about do something like that? being surprised about LA. Surprise! I have opinions. Surprise! I want things that aren’t what you want because

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I think you’re conflating two different things. Mary Ann has nothing to do with LA.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I’m conflating, motherfucker. Watch me conflate! She hangs up and visibly stamps her foot.

dialogues.speaker: PABLO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Did you just stamp your foot?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I don’t think I’ve ever done that before. I’m sorry I’m just so ANGRY. She’s handed a drink by Pablo, the tatted grip from her show. He wears a tight black T-shirt with a ratty flannel thrown over it and black jeans.

dialogues.speaker: PABLO
dialogues.text: You look like you needed one.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I do. Thanks.  93.

dialogues.speaker: PABLO
dialogues.text: You know the Japanese are making really interesting tequila right now.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (distracted) That’s exciting, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: PABLO
dialogues.text: What are you so angry about?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Ugh, my fucking ex-husband. I spend so much time feeling guilty, but he’s so self-absorbed it’s pointless. It’s a game I’m playing with myself.

dialogues.speaker: PABLO NICOLE
dialogues.text: (shaking her hand) You held the bounce board! Oh, hey, Pablo. We met at the--

dialogues.speaker: PABLO
dialogues.text: The flirty grip! INT. PABLO’S GRIP TRUCK They’re making out in the front seat. What?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Here’s what I want you to only do,

dialogues.speaker: PABLO NICOLE
dialogues.text: I want you to finger me.

dialogues.speaker: PABLO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Just finger me.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: That’s all we’re going to do, OK? Just fingering. I’m changing my whole fucking life. Fade to Black.

dialogues.speaker: NORA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Nicole and Charlie’s son, Henry, was born here in Los Angeles and currently attends Laurel Elementary in Laurel Canyon--

dialogues.speaker: INT. CONFERENCE ROOM, CENTURY CITY, LA. DAY
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Nicole.

dialogues.speaker: NORA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: --and Nicole works in Hollywood on her show while also maintaining a full schedule as a mother with classes of swim, art, gym and music as well as play groups. And then CUT TO Charlie, in a dark wool suit, who sweats.

dialogues.speaker: NORA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Nicole is Henry's primary custodial parent and to the extent that Charlie would like to exercise his custodial time, he should be making efforts to visit Henry here in California. And now INTERCUT between their two faces as if they’re having a conversation, though neither of them opens their mouth. They both listen to their representatives, sometimes with emotion, other times anger, disbelief, and self-consciousness. They occasionally look at their hands or jot down a note.

dialogues.speaker: BERT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Nora, you seem to be ignoring the fact that they lived in New York for ten years--

dialogues.speaker: NORA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: My client worked in New York, for several years--that’s true. But Nicole was born and bred right here in LA. She and Charlie would come here most holidays and summers to spend time with her family who all live here. She and Charlie were married here, would you like to see the photos? We CUT WIDE. The room has big windows with views of other surrounding glass offices.  95. Nicole sits next to Nora who looks amazing in an expensiv fitted power suit and heels. Behind them sits, Amir, Nora’s associate.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: I don’t need to see the photos-- Although I’m sure they both look beautiful-- Bert grins at Charlie who seems to be sweating through hi wool blazer. They sit across the wide table. Bert’s associate Nell behind them in a chair by the window.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: It’s my client’s expectation that after this TV show is completed, the parties will move back to New York where they currently keep an apartment--

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: And it’s my understanding that Charlie PROMISED Nicole that they would spend more time in LA during the marriage but because of Charlie’s insistence that his work keep them in New York, Nicole ended up staying much longer than she ever anticipated. In fact, a few years ago, Charlie was offered a residency at the Geffen Playhouse that would have taken his work and family to LA for a year and he turned it down knowing full well that this was Nicole’s desire.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: He wanted to maintain consistency for his family and his child.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Was this the same consistency he wanted to maintain when they went to Copenhagen for six months so he could direct a play? An assistant has her head in the door trying to get Amir’ attention.  96.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: So, while I understand that CHARLIE lives in New York and when it’s convenient for his work schedule, flies out here to see his son--

dialogues.speaker: BERT NORA
dialogues.text: He flies out here every (looking at Charlie) chance he gets at great I don’t see any reason you expense-- can’t be out here full-time. Amir acknowledges the anxious assistant and interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: AMIR
dialogues.text: Oh... Sorry. Do we want to contemplate lunch--I’1l order now so it’1l come when we’re all hungry?

dialogues.speaker: BERT AMIR
dialogues.text: Good idea. Everyone good with Manny's?

dialogues.speaker: BERT NORA
dialogues.text: I love Manny’s. (to Charlie) Have you had Manny’s? Charlie is taken aback, unsure how to process this question. He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: You’1l love it, just really yummy salads and sandwiches.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (nods ) Great. Amir passes out menus. Orders are made, Bert specifying n butter or cream. It gets to Charlie, he’s unsure.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (re: the menu) Hmm, I don’t know-- Sorry...

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (reflexively) Charlie will have the greek salad.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: OK. But with olive oil and lemon instead of the greek dressing, and I‘'1ll get the Chinese chicken salad.  97. Charlie nods, satisfied. Amir writes down the orders and hands them to an associate who exits. Nora gets up to pou herself and Nicole more coffee.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Charlie, on your grant, Nicole told me.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE BERT
dialogues.text: (can’t help but smile) He’s a genius. Thank you. He tussles Charlie’s hair. Everyone laughs awkwardly. Charlie blushes. Nicole smiles sweetly, sensing his discomfort. Nora raises a mug, offering Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: I told Nicole, I LOVED your play. You are one smart cookie. I'd love to get inside your brain!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: There was that one moment when you smell the toast. (to Amir) Smell! It was literally my favorite thing I saw that year. Truly genius.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) I was sorry to hear it closed on Broadway.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (to himself) They couldn’t smell the toast. Charlie looks at Bert, like why bring that up?

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: It’s very competitive, I imagine. Charlie nods. Nora places the coffee in front of Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Thanks.  Silence. 98.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: (launching back in) Now, whenever Charlie is in LA, Nicole, of course, agrees that it will best for Henry to see each parent equally-- (to Charlie) It’s nice out here, Charlie. You should give it a chance.

dialogues.speaker: AMIR
dialogues.text: Yeah, and the space -- you can’t beat it.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: I love it too, but all of our personal feelings about the two cities aside, we don’t share your assertion that the couple is an LA based family. It was very clearly their deal that they would go back to New York after Nicole finished her show.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: I’m not aware of any deal.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (can’t help himself) I didn’t get it in writing.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Charlie, is this like the deal you made that you and Nicole would spend more time in LA during the marriage?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (flustered) We didn’t have a deal. It was something we discussed...but...

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: So, it’s a deal when it’s something you want, but it’s a discussion when Nicole wants it?

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Sidebar! (putting his hand on Charlie’s arm) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nora, is there a spare office, where Charlie and I could sidebar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, windowless, bare impersonal room with a table, a phone, some left-out coffee cups and a plate with crumbs.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: (a bit overwhelmed) Nora’s a very good lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE BERT
dialogues.text: Uh huh. (impressed) Tough, right?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: And you're in a bind because you’ve shown that you’re willing to fly out here and rent an apartment to see your son--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You told me to do that!

dialogues.speaker: BERT CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I know that. And I'm doing that because I want to see my kid. Not to set a precedent.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Yes, but unfortunately you are setting a precedent. And a judge may look at it that way.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What's the alternative? I stay in New York and never come out here?

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: No, because then it will look to the court like you don’t care about seeing your son.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Court or no court, stop saying court and then never court!

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Well, the way this is going, we might have to go to court.  100.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Are you aware how maddening you sound?

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: I am. And I know it seems unfair. But imagine if you were a poor mother abandoned by her husband who refuses to pay anything. That’s what the system is trying to protect people from. Charlie nods.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Listen, if I were representing you--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You are representing me.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Right, no, of course. I don’t see a judge moving this child from LA-- I think we try to settle today--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Settle meaning... what?

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: She gets LA, but--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (upset) No, Bert... just NO. I mean, we have to win this?

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Remember, the win is what’s best for Henry. And if you guys go to court, he’1ll get pulled into it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: If he stays out here and I stay in New York, that’s just, then I won’t, I’ll never get to really be his parent again.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: It'll be different.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It won’t exist!  101.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Maybe you move here. You heard what Amir said about the space.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Fuck the space, Bert. FUCK THE SPACE.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: I’1l do whatever you want me to do, but this is my advice. I’ve seen these things go on and on and the burden of these battles is immeasurable. I had a client get colon cancer and die before he and his wife came to agreement.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What about filing in New York?

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: It’s too late and even if you did, I don’t think it would matter. They’re being reasonable financially. You’re lucky they’re not asking for half of your grant money--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: She wouldn’t do that. She knows, I put all that money back in my theater.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: If this continues, she might.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The actors and crew all rely on that money, they have families and- - A court would never agree with this, right?

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Whether they do or not, it’1ll cost you half your grant money anyway to go to court and prove it. Charlie deflates.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I feel like a criminal.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: But you didn’t commit any crime.  102.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It doesn’t feel that way.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: If we give on LA right now and try to make the best deal possible, I think we can get her to give on some other fronts.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: There are no other fronts. This is the thing. (suddenly emotional) He needs to know that I fought for him.

dialogues.speaker: BERT CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He’1l know. (dismayed) I don’t-- I should never have let her come out here with Henry.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: If it wasn’t LA and New York it would be something else. You'd be fighting over a house or school district or... It’s like the joke about the woman at the hairdresser who's going to Rome--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE BERT
dialogues.text: A woman is at her hairdresser’s and she says, “Oh, I’m going to Rome on holiday” and the hairdresser says-- Charlie stares at the clock on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: “What airline are you taking?” And she says, “Al Italia.” And he says, “Oh that’s the worst airline I’ve--" He continues the joke as Charlie observes the second hand moving around the circle. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Bert, but am I paying for this joke? Bert hesitates.  103.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: No matter what happens here, it’s temporary. He’s growing up, he’s going to have opinions on the subject. Time is on your side, Charlie. Maybe he’1ll do college on the East Coast. CUT TO: Henry’s face. He’s talking animatedly about how much money he has in his piggybank.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I have my quarters and dimes at Daddy’s, but I’m keeping my dollars and my one twenty with you, OK? Charlie watches him. INT. CHARLIE’S RENTAL APARTMENT. EVENING Nicole's face is on the computer screen in front of Henry He’s doing Face Time with her. The place is small and mostly bare with furniture that ca with it. CLOSE: A bill from Bert’s firm for 25 thousand dollars. Charlie sits at a table with a stack of bills, legal letters, and a checkbook open. He hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Goddamn it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What's goddamn it?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Did you lose power where you are?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Dad, did we lose power?!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (looking up) No.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: It’s back on now. There are rolling blackouts in the hills but now the gate won’t close.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Her gate won’t close!  104. EXT. NICOLE’S NEW HOUSE, ECHO PARK. NIGHT Nicole stands outside in the dark. The gate is wide open. Charlie appears from the shadows holding Henry’s hand. Henry runs and hugs his mom.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You tried all the--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I tried everything.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Can I look at my room?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Of course. Henry runs inside. They remain outside.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I made you come It's fine-- out--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s just-- You don’t want your gate open.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: There should be a panel or something either inside or-- She stands in the threshold, blocking his path. She point toward a white box amongst trees in the yard.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I think this is something-- He steps over some bushes and inspects the alarm system.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s a cute house.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (pleased) I mean, from what I can see. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: You’re getting shaggy.  105.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I have to find a haircutter.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (pause) Do you want me to cut it?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (hesitates) OK.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I'll get scissors. EXT. NICOLE’S PORCH Charlie, shirtless, a towel around his shoulders, sits ve still on a chair. Nicole cuts his hair. The porch light illuminating.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Close your eyes. Charlie does. CLOSE on the scissors snipping across his shut eyes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NICOLE'S NEW PLACE. ECHO PARK, LA. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Nicole carries the sleeping Henry. They both smile at the sweetness. Henry stirs.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: He’s out. Maybe he should stay here tonight--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s my night. She nods and hands him to Charlie. CUT TO: Charlie and a tired Henry pull on the gate. Nicol helps, dragging from the other side. It starts to close. They yank it shut, closing her in and them out. We CUT QUICKLY between them both just as it closes. We stay with her. Fade to Black. The sound of a couple loudly arguing in Spanish.  106.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LOS ANGELES COURTHOUSE, HALLWAY. MORNING
dialogues.text: A man and woman are shouting at each other. The lawyers trying to separate them. Various benches are filled with the other divorcing couples, men and women sitting apart from one another with their individual representatives. In their midst, Nora and Nicole sit on a bench in the wid dingy hallway. Amir sorts through documents nearby.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: I think we’re mostly finished. Bert and I hammered out ninety- percent of the details, there’s a couple minor things hanging that should be easy and then the judge will make your divorce official.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: OK, good--

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: I hear the tracking for your show is off the chain--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Oh, I don’t even know what that means, but good I guess--

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: I made sure the date of separation came AFTER the pilot pick-up to protect that money-- (suddenly) Fuck me.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: What? She follows Nora’s gaze to Jay Marotta who marches down t hallway, conferring with Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: It’s not television. It’s not a wise judge played by a great character actor. These are just people open to manipulation like anyone else. You think it’s justice, but it’s not.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Who is that?  107.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Charlie shouldn’t have done this.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Where’s Bert?

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: It means everything we’ve agreed upon is now off the table. Jay and Charlie take a bench a ways away. Jay says Hi to some other lawyers.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: But, we’ve got LA, right--

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Not with Jay Marotta representing him. This is a street fight now. And I'm going to have to ask for things we wouldn’t normally ask for. We’ll need as much leverage as possible to negotiate with. Nora rises with a pinched smile--

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: This system rewards bad behavior. --and greets Jay. Nicole looks over at Charlie who doesn’t meet her eye.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COURT ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: The low hum of a copier machine and periodic mouse-clicks from a computer.

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: A little history. Jay speaks in front of the judge who clearly has a bad cold. Charlie sits at the end of the table with Ted, the associate. Nicole is at the corresponding end of an adjacent table next to Nora and Amir.

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: Ten years ago, Charlie takes a risk when he first hires Nicole as an actress in his play in New York City. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s a well regarded, up and coming director of the avant garde and she’s known as the girl in that college sex movie who takes her top off.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: My client will not be slut- shamed for an artistic choice. Nora takes a moment.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Charlie has just received the enormous sum of six hundred and fifty thousand dollars in the form of a MacArthur grant for the theater work he has conducted during the marriage.

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: Ten years on and many prestigious theater roles later, she’s become an actress of great credibility. And because of this credibility, she’s offered a lead roll ona major television show. new opportunity in her is thanks to Charlie. Your honor, I don’t see why we should be paying any support money at this point. In fact, Charlie should be entitled to half of her TV salary, present and future earnings on the show. This life

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: Of which he gets in 125 thousand installments over five years, money that is used to employ actors and crew members and to pay back debts he’s accumulated with his theater company that stars his wife. By Jay’s same logic, this is work that Nicole contributed to in numerous ways. Not give up a lucrative career in movies to little theater, she Charlie with a loan help out.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: Which he paid back-- only did she and successful perform in his also supplied early on to

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: She lent her name to the Marquee and was the principle reason people came to the theater.  109.

dialogues.speaker: JAY NORA
dialogues.text: That may have been true ten She, in turn, helped years ago-- establish Charlie's reputation. Charlie looks over at Nicole. She looks down.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Over the next ten years she was subsequently offered parts in movies, TV shows, most of which she turned down at Charlie’s bequest to be a mother and to act in his plays. Now, while we’re willing to be flexible on support we contend that half of Charlie’s grant money should be split between the parties. Charlie looks at Jay. oh,

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: I don’t see how you can claim that she gets half a grant dedicated to his genius.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: He became a genius during the course of the marriage.

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA NORA
dialogues.text: come on, Nora. Charlie, himself, upon hearing he received the prize, told Nicole it belonged to her too.

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: That’s something people say when they win awards.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: No, he was implying what was true: his genius was an intangible asset built during the marriage. Charlie and Nicole both stare at the floor.  110.

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: Nora, I like how you refer to Charlie’s theater as a ramshackled downtown dump when you’re arguing custody, but when you want more money, Charlie’s a big rich genius Broadway director. You can’t have it both ways.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Why not? And whether you think it’s fair or not, Jay, the first monetary installment from the MacArthur grant was then put in a joint marital account and thus became community property so this and any further installments should be split between the parties. Jay whispers to Charlie. Jay turns

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: Fuck. You shouldn’t have put that money in the joint account.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: There’s not going to be anything left anyway, I’m using it all to divorce her... back to Nora.

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: Nora, I have to say your account of this marriage takes place in an alternate reality. By suddenly MOVING to LA, and insisting on an LA residence, Nicole is withholding Henry, alienating him from his father. This has turned Charlie’s world upside down. It amounts to an ambush.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Withholding, Jay? Really? Alienating. Those are fighting words and it is simply false and does nothing to further our settlement. Your recap of this situation is outrageous. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: NORA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And although California is, without doubt, a no-fault state, it does bear mentioning in the accurate recap of this situation that Charlie had had extramarital affairs--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: AN extramarital affair. Nora turns and stares at Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Do you really want me to go there?

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: Let’s go there. Nicole has admitted to HACKING Charlie’s computer and reading his emails. Nora turns to Nicole who shrugs. Jay stands.

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: Which if proven is a felony. And Nora, I don’t think you’1l be happy if I start to ask Nicole about her alcohol consumption in the evenings--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA
dialogues.text: She confided in Charlie one night recently, having just carried Henry to bed, that she was having trouble standing while walking down the staircase. From what I understand this was not an isolated event. You let me know, Nora, otherwise we'll go there as needed. Jay sits back down. Nicole stares at Charlie who looks humiliated.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Charlie, can I ask you: How can you expect to have more time with Henry when you don’t exercise the time you have AND exercise it responsibly. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: NORA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: On a recent visit to Los Angeles, after failing to text, call or communicate in any way, shape or form, Charlie finally arrived two hours late to pick up Henry at Nicole’s mother’s house. At that point the car seat which he assured Nicole had been professionally installed was clearly not even belted in, just sitting on the back seat. Jay turns to Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You have to buckle the seat I know that. I thought the in, man, it’s the law. car rental place did it.

dialogues.speaker: JAY MAROTTA CHARLIE
dialogues.text: They can’t do it, it’sa I know that NOW! Once we liability-- discovered that, we fixed it. The judge wipes his runny nose and interrupts-- Charlie's

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: politely.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: (to Jay and Nora) Counsel, you can see my courtroom is full and there are people who don’t have the resources your clients have. And I’m fairly certain you haven’t exhausted in good faith the arguments in the case of this child. In the meantime, we'll keep the status quo. This remains an LA family for the time being. face drops.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I took over this department recently and am still becoming acquainted with the cases so I’m going to appoint an expert evaluator who knows much more about young children than I do. Once the evaluation is done we'll modify the orders where necessary. door opens revealing Nicole. She smiles

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CHARLIE'S RENTAL APARTMENT. DAY
dialogues.text: Charlie, somewhat formally, ushers her in. 113.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Where’s Henry?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He’s with Cassie and her You want something to drink? kids at Laser Tag.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I have unfiltered tap water, beer and some juice boxes.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I’1l have a juice box. He goes into the kitchen. She looks at his rental place. It makes her sad.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: You don’t have anything on the walls.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don’t have anything to put on them except Henry’s art which is being framed.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I can give you some things, you know until you get some stuff... How about that great picture of Henry on the Staten Island Ferry--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Aren't you in that one?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh, right, I guess I am. Oh, I’m going to have to (shrugs) leave a day early to go to I guess you can cut me out? New York on the 22nd so I was wondering if I could take Henry that Friday--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: The 22nd? So, that’s the 21st? We have plans actually. We’re going to this thing at LACMA with the cousins--  114. He reappears and hands her a juice box.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: But could you change it so I It’s only that night. He’s can take him-- looking forward to it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: It’s my night, Charlie, we negotiated it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: (coldly) I mean...what? OK. Fine.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, I’m just asking you to be flexible--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I AM flexible. You come in and out and I adjust based on your schedule. This one night we happen to have to have tickets to a thing. I mean...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s not only this one night, but fine... She opens the straw, and uses it to puncture the hole and sips the drink.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Henry’s teacher wants to meet with us.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You mean his LA teacher--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Can you respond to the email Yeah, I’ve been distracted. so we can set a time?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I understand. They just want to rule out everything, you know, with his reading.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I think he’s just over-anxious. I think he wants it so much.  115.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I know, he quits too easily They said he’s off the if things aren’t easy for charts in math. him. You know, he’s like us, he’s stubborn.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: He’s still a lousy Monopoly player because he tries to save all his money. Charlie laughs. Nicole smiles.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: So... I thought we should talk.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: Uh huh. I feel like maybe things have gone too far.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I mean, my mom has taken out a loan against the house to help me pay Nora-

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I thought I pay Nora.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: You pay thirty percent of Nora.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, I’m going broke too if that’s any help. I’ve just agreed to direct two shitty plays and we can forget putting anything away for Henry’s college.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (trying not to take the bait) It’s just that...up until now we've been able to keep Henry at least somewhat removed. And this will change that.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: Uh huh. And we have to protect him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I agree.  116.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Nora says the evaluator will come into our homes. She’ll interview Henry in addition to us, our family, friends, enemies... And then she’1l observe us with him, how we are as parents.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Sounds awful.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I know! I feel like if anyone observed me on any given day as a mom, I’d never get custody. (pause) That was a joke.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I know. I feel the same way.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (smiles) Right. So, maybe we can figure something out between us--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You’1l remember I said this to you at the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I know you did, but these are different circumstances--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: I was anticipating these Mm hm. Anyway... Shall we circumstances-- try this?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (pause) There’s a long silence. They both laugh.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know how to start...

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Do you understand why I want to stay in LA?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Well, that’s not...Charlie, that’s not a useful way for us to start--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t understand it.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: You don’t remember promising that we could do time out here?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We discussed things. We were married, we said things. We talked about moving to Europe, about getting a sideboard or what do you call it, a credenza, to fill that empty space behind the couch. We never did any of it.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And you turned down that It wasn’t something I residency at the Geffen that wanted. We had a great would have brought us here theater company and a great and-- life where we were.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: You call that a great life.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Me discovering you're Don’t pretend you’re not fucking Mary Ann-- capable of deception. You left Ben for ME.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t mean we had a great marriage. I mean, life in Brooklyn... Professionally. I don’t know. Honestly I never considered anything different.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Well, that’s the problem isn’t it? I was your wife, you should have considered my happiness too.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Come on! You WERE happy. You’ve just decided you weren’t now--  We did say I thought- 118.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (not taking the bait) So, OK, let’s... I work here now. My family is here.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And I agreed to put Henry in school here because your show went to series. I did that KNOWING that when you were done shooting, he would come back to New York...

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Honey, we never said that. That might have been your assumption, but we never expressly said that...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: it. When did we say it?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know when we said it, but we said it!

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (remembering something) We said it that time on the phone--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Let me finish. Honey-- (hesitates, angry at herself) Sorry, I keep saying THAT. (resumes ) I thought...that if Henry was happy out here and my show continued, that we might do LA for a while.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I was not privy to that thought process.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: The only reason we didn’t live here was because you can’t imagine desires other than your own unless they’re forced on you.  119.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: OK, you wish you hadn’t married me, you wish you'd had a different life. But this is what happened.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (trying to stay calm) So what do we do?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Nora says there’s no coming back from this.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Fuck Nora. I hate fucking Nora telling me I always lived in LA even though I never lived in LA. How could you have her say those things about me?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Jay said them about me too! (hesitates) You shouldn’t have fired Bert.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I needed my own asshole!

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Let’s both agree both of our lawyers have said shitty stuff about both of us--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Nora was worse.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Jay called me an alcoholic! You pulled the rug out from under me and you’re putting me through hell--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You put me through hell Is that what that was? DURING the marriage! Hell?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: And now you're going to put Henry through this horrible thing so you can yet again get what you want.  120.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s not what I want...I mean, it’s what I want, but it’s what was...WAS...what’s best for him.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I was wondering when you’d get around to Henry and what HE actually wants.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, fuck off--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: No, YOU fuck off. If you listened to your son, or anyone, he’d tell you he’d rather live here.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: Stop putting your feelings He tells me he likes it here about me onto Henry. better.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He tells you because he knows it’s what you want to HEAR!

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: He tells me you’re on the phone all the time. You don’t even play with him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: Because I’m going through a You're fighting for divorce in LA and trying to something you don’t even direct a play in New York. WANT.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Which closed because I wasn’t THERE! That was a HUGE opportunity for me. For the theater. And I let everyone down.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: You’re being so much like your father.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: DO NOT compare me to my father.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I didn’t compare you. I said you were acting like him.  121.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You're exactly like your mother! Everything you complain about her, you’re doing. You’re suffocating

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: First of all, I love my I’m just repeating what mother, she was a great you've told me-- mother!

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Secondly, how dare you compare my mothering to my mother? I might be like my father, but I’m NOT like my mother.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You ARE! And you’re like my father. You’re also like MY mother. You’re all the bad things about all of these people. But mostly your mother. When we would lie in bed together, sometimes I would look at you and see HER and just feel so GROSS.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I felt repulsed when you touched me.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
