dialogues.text: You’re a slob. I made all The thought of having sex the beds, closed all the with you makes me want to cabinets, picked up after peel my skin off. you like an infant--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You'll never be happy. In LA or anywhere. You’ll think you found some better, opposite guy than me and in a few years you’ll rebel against him because you need to have your VOICE. But you don’t WANT a voice. You just want to fucking complain about not having a VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I think of being married to you and that woman is a stranger to me.  122.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: You’ve regressed. You've We had a child’s marriage. gone back to your life before you met me. It’s pathetic.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: People used to say to me that you were too selfish to be a great artist. I used to defend you. But they’re absolutely right.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: All your best acting is You gaslighted me. You’re a behind you. You’re back to fucking villain. being a HACK.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You want to present yourself as a victim because it’s a good legal strategy, FINE. But you and I both know you CHOSE this life. You wanted it until you didn’t. Nicole is silent.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You USED me so you could get out of LA.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I didn’t use you-- You did and then you BLAMED me for it. You always made me aware of what I was doing wrong, how I was falling short.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Life with you was JOYLESS.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: So you had to fuck someone else? How could you?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You shouldn’t be upset that I fucked her, you should be upset that I had a laugh with her.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Do you love her?  123.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No! But she didn’t hate me. You hated me.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: You hated ME. You fucked someone we worked with.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You stopped having sex with me in the last year. I never cheated on you.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: That was cheating on me.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: But there’s so much I could have done. I was a director in my 20's who came from nothing and was suddenly on the cover of fucking Time Out New York. I was hot shit—-and I wanted to fuck EVERYBODY and I didn’t. And I loved you and didn’t want to lose you...and I’m in my twenties and I didn’t want to lose that too. And you wanted SO much so fast...I didn’t even want to get married...and fuck it, there’s so much I DIDN’T do.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Well, thanks for that.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You’re welcome. You’re...welcome. Nicole stamps her feet and shakes her fists like a child having a tantrum.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I can’t believe I have to know you

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You’re fucking insane! Charlie raises his arm and punches the wall. The cheap dr wall cracks and chips.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And you're fucking winning.  124.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? I wanted to be married. I’d ALREADY LOST. (sadly) You didn’t love me as much as I loved you.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (pause) What does that have to do with LA? Nicole stares at him, incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: What? You’re so merged with your own selfishness that you don’t even identify it as selfishness anymore. YOU'RE SUCH A DICK.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Every day I wake up and hope you’re dead-- Dead like-- And then Charlie starts crying.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (through tears) If I could guarantee Henry would be OK, I’d hope you get an illness and then get hit by a car and DIE. He sinks down, weeping. All this vitriol has taken its toll. Nicole watches, taken aback. She walks over and gently puts her hand on his shoulder. He shakes and cries

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I know. Finally, he looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: SET DESIGNER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Try the chair by the window...  125. INT. CHARLIE’S RENTAL. DAY Charlie gets a delivery of rental plates, glasses, furniture, plants. He stands on his balcony directing the delivery men. Charlie set-decorates his rental. He Skypes with Agnes, his set designer from the theater. Holding out the computer to show her the apartment. He buys a stack of board games with Henry. He and Henry get Henry’s drawings at framer. They hang the art-work.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Why do we have so many plants all of a sudden?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We'll have to return some of this stuff so don’t get too used to it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: My mom is the last person to turn into a plant on her show.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (nervously touching a fern) I find plants kind of scary.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: These plants are good guys. (hesitates) Hey, tomorrow this woman is going to come and visit us and be with us while we eat dinner.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Is it your girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, no...

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Mommy's boyfriend?  126.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, why...does Mommy have a boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Does she?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Why is someone watching us eat dinner?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I know, it’s weird. It’s just something we have to do which has to do with Mommy and me figuring out everything...and how we’re going to be and...you know?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Will you read to me? Charlie and Henry lie down on the floor against the blank wall and Charlie starts reading to him.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Any history of domestic violence?

dialogues.speaker: INT. OFFICE. DAY
dialogues.text: We STAY on Nicole who sits facing an unseen evaluator.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Oh... No. You mean coming from me? No. Not coming from him either...

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Have you been to prison?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Yes, actually. Well, not prison. Jail. But it was deliberate.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I was demonstrating as part of a Grandmothers for Peace rally. I was with my mom, but she didn’t go to jail. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: with? OK. 127.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (laughs, remembering) Somehow she avoided that part. But I did.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Do you use drugs or alcohol?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I drink alcohol.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How much alcohol do you drink?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Glass of wine with dinner. Sometimes more?

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How much more?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Well, sometimes, a few... I sometimes split a bottle of wine with someone?

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who do you split it I mean, if I’m having dinner with someone and we order a bottle of wine.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You know, like if you’re at a restaurant and you say, “Should we go by the glass or get a bottle?”

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You get a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Sometimes! Sometimes I go by the glass. You know, it depends... (hesitates) Do you mean drugs ever? I have done drugs. In college. I don’t do it regularly.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Anything since you've been a mother?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Pot a few times. Coke once at a party. But Henry wasn’t with me.  Silence. 128.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What would you say are your strengths as a parent?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I listen. I play. I put in the time. I love taking care of him, watching him grow up... Sometimes it’s true what they say about it goes so fast, but sometimes it’s not. Sometimes it goes too slow, honestly...

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What are your weaknesses?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I’m too precise. I care too much.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Are those weaknesses?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (smiles) Maybe not. (thinks) You know what, he can be an asshole and I can get really pissed off. I/’11 call him on being an asshole and--

dialogues.speaker: NORA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m going to stop you there. Nora stands up from behind the female associate who is doing the practice interview with Nicole. We’re in Nora’s office.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Don’t ever say that. People don’t accept a mother who drinks too much wine and yells at her child and calls him an asshole. I get it. I do it too. While she talks she also texts and addresses emails on he phone.  129.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: We can accept an imperfect Dad. Let’s face it, the idea of a good father was only invented like 30 years ago. Before that fathers were expected to be silent and absent and unreliable and selfish and we can all say that we want them to be different but on some basic level we ACCEPT them, we LOVE them for their fallibilities. But people absolutely DON’T accept those same failings in mothers. (building up steam) We don't accept it structurally and we don't accept it spiritually because the basis of our Judeo- Christian Whatever is Mary Mother of Jesus and she’s PERFECT. She’s a virgin who gives birth, unwaveringly supports her child, and holds his dead body when he’s gone. But the Dad isn’t there. He didn’t even do the fucking because God’s in heaven. God is the father and God didn't show up so you have to be perfect and Charlie can be a fuck up and it doesn't matter. You’1ll always be held to a different, higher standard and it’s FUCKED up, but that’s the way it is.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CHARLIE'S RENTAL APARTMENT. EVENING
dialogues.text: Charlie is cooking an elaborate dinner. The bell rings. He takes a deep breath. He glances into Henry’s room. He’s playing by himself on the floor. He walks through the set-decorated living room which look relatively homey, full of warmth and board games and pictures of Charlie and Henry. Charlie opens the door. A diminutive woman with frizzy hair is staring at the door across the hall. She startles turns around and smiles and puts out her hand.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: I think I rang the wrong bell. Nancy Katz.  130.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (shaking) Hi, I’m Charlie Barber. Nancy, can I get you anything?

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m easy. A glass of water? Kitchen. Charlie opens up a cabinet. Plates. He opens another cabinet. Pots. A third cabinet. Empty. Finally he finds glasses in a low cupboard. He glances back at th evaluator who waits patiently.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s a new apartment. Charlie and Nancy take their drinks to the dining room table.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Shall we go in here?

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: Sure. What’s a day like for the two of you here?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, if he has school, I take him there, of course and pick him up, assuming I can do both.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: What prevents you from picking him up?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Um, you know, work. I’m preparing a play I’m directing in a few months.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: Oh, what is that?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Kasimir and Karoline by Odon von Horvath? We’re doing it at the Barrow in New York.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: So, you have to be away?  131.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes. Recently, since Nicole has been working on this show in LA, I come back and forth a lot.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: That sounds difficult.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It is. And expensive. I’11 try to take him with me some of the time, but Nicole doesn’t like for him to fly so much.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: That can be hard on a child. All that recycled air.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Well, he’s sturdy.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: Some parents won't take their kids to a restaurant because of these super bugs.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: Uh huh. (looking at her notes) I notice on one visit to Los Angeles, you came on a Sunday and left ona Thursday. Why not stay for a weekend?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh...on that time, I had tech for Electra back in New York.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: It was my Broadway debut. I don’t know what tech is.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s the technical part of the production. You figure out the lights and--

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (moving forward) (still explaining) And what's a weekend day Monday is our day off in like? theater--  132.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (discovering his mouth is dry) Well, out here he has basketball on Saturday at 12, 11, I’m sorry and so we go there. (swallowing) And then afterwards, maybe we’1ll get lunch somewhere and then if there’s a movie to see...

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: Does he like basketball?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He does. His coach, um, Rick says he’s a good dribbler and I’ve seen that...

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Ron. I’m sorry. His coach’s name is Ron. Rick’s his dentist in New York. The evaluator writes something in her book.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, you know our home home was...is in New York. That’s where we live and--

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: New York is a long way from here.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We like it because we can walk.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: You can walk here.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: And the space. Charlie nods. CUT TO: HENRY’S ROOM Henry plays on the floor. The evaluator sits in a chair.  133.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: Do you like your school?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I love it.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: What's your favorite part about it?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Maybe gym.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You like math--

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Math is boring. Charlie enters and hands Henry a plate with cut-up apple. Henry takes it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You’re welcome. But you’re getting really good at it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, you are, but... Charlie exits.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: What do you and your Dad like to do together?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: When I’m at my Dad’s we sometimes watch a movie or build a Lego or something. My Dad’s a great Lego builder. Nancy smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Charlie listening at the door, smiles.  134.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And at your mom’s?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: At home, I have most of my toys and- Charlie bristles at the word “home” used to describe Nicole's. HENRY’S ROOM

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: --there’s a pool and I have a tree- house and jungle gym. We play lots of games. We have Super Secret Treasure Hunt which is really fun. Cut TO: KITCHEN Charlie is making ground meat and potatoes and spinach. H has a lot of burners going at once, making a mess.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Sweetheart, do you want to help me set the table.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Do I have to?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Just come in here and grab a plate and--

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m playing.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Henry! HENRY’S ROOM Henry plays with his men on the floor. The evaluator sits in a chair nearby.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (grudgingly) O-K. Henry gets off his chair and goes into--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why are you being like this?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: If I ask you to help out, help out.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (eating something from the pan) What is this?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s special meal.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What are the green things? There aren’t green things in special meal.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s just a garnish.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Here, I’1ll take it off.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to eat anything it touched.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It doesn’t change the taste of anything.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I might want to be a vegetarian. Mom's a vegetarian.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Is she a vegetarian now?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (prickly) Well, then you should like garnish. It’s all garnish, vegetarianism.  136. Charlie looks over. Nancy stands, watching, in the threshold of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: I’m done with my water. She returns her water to the sink.

dialogues.speaker: DINING AREA
dialogues.text: Charlie and Henry eat. Nancy sits with them.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You sure you don’t want anything?

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: No, I’m fine, thank you. They eat in silence. The evaluator observing.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Do the thing with the knife.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No...I’m not...no.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Come on!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s not a dinner thing. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s not an anytime thing.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: What's the thing with the knife?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It’s hilarious.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No...it’s dumb. I have a small knife on my keychain. Which is only for adults. I do a thing with it sometimes...

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You said I could get a knife.  137.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: A jack-knife, yeah. When you're older.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Like ten.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, like twenty.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Charlie watches the evaluator’s face closely, trying to discern something, anything.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Charlie and Henry do his homework. Henry is sounding out word.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Dime, rime, lime, pime, sime--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Honey, stop guessing. You’re so close, stay with it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (lying on his back) Ugh, I don’t want to do it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What’s the first letter?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to do it. Can I do the iPad?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No. Just look, what’s the first letter?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to. It’s a T. What sound does T make.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (pause) Tuh.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Right and then just do the rest of it.  138.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Dime.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No! You have “Tuh” and “ime.” What is that? Henry takes a piece of tape and puts it on his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Time. It’s time. He looks at the evaluator. She nods. Henry rolls over onto his front, playing dead.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You’1l see, honey, one day it’s just going to click and you’1l be able to read everything.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (through the tape) I need a break. Can I play in my room?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Sure. Charlie tries to kiss him on lips. Henry gives him his head. Charlie kisses the top of his head. Henry runs out. Nancy is looking at the crack in the wall from Charlie’s punch. Charlie clocks this. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Do you ever observe married people?

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: No, why would I?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I was kidding.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: Oh. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The knife thing is, I carry this knife on my keychain which his mother got me actually--  139. He takes out his key-ring and shows her the X-Acto knife.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: --and I’d do this thing for his mom-- He clicks open the knife.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Where I pretend to cut myself, but I retract the blade-- He pantomimes cutting his arm.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: But I don’t do it with him... The evaluator stares at Charlie with horror. Charlie hesitates and follows her gaze. Dark red blood streams down his arm.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh...that’s fine. It’s really bleeding. He covers it with his hand, the blood spreading between his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: Are you OK?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (casually) Yeah, I must not have retracted the blade all the way.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: Do you need-- Blood is getting over everything. He lowers the sleeve on his oxford shirt to cover the wound. Red blots immediatel soak through the cotton.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah...yeah. No! I’m fine. (smiles at her and crosses his legs) What else can I tell you?

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: I think I have enough.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (again trying to talk casually) You got enough?  140.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: (winces) Are you sure you’re OK?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Totally. I’m fine. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: Well, I’1l leave you guys for tonight.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, OK...

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: I‘1l be in touch if I have further questions. She stands and gathers her things while Charlie grabs her coat from a chair and holds it out to her, his left shirt arm growing crimson. She takes it, trying to avoid the blood.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: Thanks. She climbs into her coat, Charlie nominally helping out with his good arm, and moves toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: Thank you for the water.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, sure.

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: You’re sure you’re OK?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (too loud) Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: EVALUATOR
dialogues.text: Bye bye.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Bye. She tries to open the door, but it’s locked. She turns a bolt and another latch but it still won’t open.  141.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, let me-- Charlie rushes over and undoes the bolt. She tries to get out of the way of the blood, while he reaches his long ar around her to do this, putting them both in a strangely intimate proximity. He pulls and it won’t open.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I think you turned-- He does the latch and finally it opens.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Sorry. She flushes and smiles awkwardly and slips out, closing t door behind her. Charlie runs into the kitchen, swaying, leaning against t wall for support. His shirt is now soaked in blood. He rolls up his sleeve, and runs cold water on his arm. He winces. Watery blood fills up the pots and pans in the sink mixing with whatever bits of remaining food. He finds a small box of band-aids in the cupboard and ope about seven of them and tries to cover up the wound. But it’s still really bleeding. He wraps his arm in paper towels, sweat now sliding down his face and soaking his armpits. He drops to the kitchen floor and lies down on his back in exhaustion and pain. Two small bare feet step over him and pad over to the refrigerator.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Dad, are you OK?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m just tired. Charlie rolls over onto his arm, hiding it from Henry. Th sound of milk being poured into a glass. Then the feet re approach and step back over Charlie. Little drips of milk whiten the floor.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (sleepily) Dad, did she like us?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (from the floor) Yeah, she thought we were great.  142. Fade to Black. INT. NICOLE’S NEW PLACE. ECHO PARK, LA. DAY Cassie, Sandra and Nicole sing “You Could Drive a Person Crazy” from the musical, Company -- The tight harmonies a sung a capella, and there are dance moves to go along wit it. The group of people watching includes kids and an agent, cast and crew from her show and family -- it’s a housewarming party. (The house looks very different from the home she shared with Charlie. More color, more patterns, more hippy-dippy more lamps, more her. It’s how she likes it.) They finish their song and everyone applauds, kind of to polite, but also because it was seriously, strangely grea INT. NICOLE’S KITCHEN. LATER Nora pops the cork on a big bottle of Cristal. Nicole is getting food together for the guests, pulling saran wrap off platters. She leaves cabinet doors open which she maneuvers around. Kids run through the room playing. Guests enter to grab drinks, etc.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: I want your mom!

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Oh really? Yeah-- Nora makes a heart symbol with her hands and leaps up on the kitchen counter, swinging her feet and drinking champagne like a teenager.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: So, because Charlie dropped his claim to New York, we’re mostly done. Jay’s lost interest and Ted, his associate, is doing the paper work.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: And we're not taking any money, right?  143.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: We withdrew the claim for the MacArthur, which I think we could have gotten by the way, and they’re not asking for any of the show.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (clinking glasses) OK, good. Thank you for everything, Nora

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: You’re welcome, doll. (pause) And when Charlie’s in LA, I got the custody breakdown to be 55/45, so you'll have Henry one extra day every two weeks...

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I thought we made it equal.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: I tweaked it at the last minute. I just didn’t want him to be able to say he got 50/50.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE NORA
dialogues.text: But I don’t-- Bragging to his friends.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: --want to do that.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Take it! You won.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (sadly) Uh huh. INT. NICOLE’S KITCHEN, LA. DAY CLOSE on Nicole writing her signature. She uses the last name (her maiden name) Ryder. Nicole sits at her kitchen table in LA.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE'S APARTMENT, NEW YORK. DAY
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Charlie writing his signature. Charlie sits on the floor of his half-empty apartment.  144.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FLATBUSH AVENUE, BROOKLYN. DAY
dialogues.text: An ASPCA guy approaches him smiling.

dialogues.speaker: ASPCA GUY
dialogues.text: You look like a guy who really cares about animals--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LAUNDROMAT, BROOKLYN. DAY
dialogues.text: He watches a mother and father with a young baby in the stroller.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BARBER SHOP, BROOKLYN. DAY
dialogues.text: Charlie sits in a barber’s chair getting a haircut.

dialogues.speaker: INT. RESTAURANT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Charlie enters the same restaurant we saw everyone at for the closing night party so many months before. He sees Mary Ann and Terry and a couple of other actors. piano player, actors singing, performing. He joins his old group. The gang is happy to see him. He opens a tab at the bar for everyone. They all sit at a booth, having been drinking for a while now.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: .»..and the couch was technically hers pre-marriage, but, I mean, it was OUR couch, it’s not like I was going to BUY another couch but then when it comes time to split, it’s suddenly HER couch and I have no couch and-- I’m sitting on the floor is the short version. (waves his hand) I’m sorry. This is all so self- pitying and boring.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, no, no, sounds really No, it’s all stupid. I’m tough. sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MARY ANN
dialogues.text: (pointedly) No, it’s sad.  145. The piano player plays the opening notes of a song. Charlie recognizes it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: “Someone to hold you too close...” He gets up and walks to the piano. People know who he is, and are intrigued to see what he’s going to do. Sings “Being Alive” from Company. It’s sloppy, but surprisingly emotional and comes from a deep place. And i the end is beautiful. Fade to Black. EXT./INT. SANDRA’S HOUSE, WEST HOLLYWOOD, LOS ANGELES. DA Charlie gets out of his rental car. He knocks on the back door. No answer. He apprehensively opens the screen door to the kitchen. Food is on the stove. Music plays. It’s warm and welcoming. But Charlie remains in the threshold.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hello? He hears laughter from the other rooms. And then Henry shouting excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hello? Suddenly Carter runs, breathlessly, into the kitchen. He clutches a ray gun.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: You’1l never take me! He sees Charlie and hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hi. Sorry, the door was open. Carter puts his finger up to his lips.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: Shhh.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh...OK.  146. The electronic sound of something bad happening. Carter’s been hit in laser tag. Sandra runs in holding a gun.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: I got you! She hesitates when she sees Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Charlie, hi. She comes forward and hugs him. It isn’t cold particularly, but it isn’t what it was. Carter extends hi hand.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: Carter.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: Nicole’s still at work. Silence. Then Henry enters.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Can I get a hug? Henry hugs Charlie. Charlie smiles at everyone awkwardly. CUT TO: Charlie, Sandra and Carter talk at the dining roo table. Nicole arrives from filming her show. Carter rises, they kiss.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: How'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Good. Donny’s dead now. I shot the scene where he merges with the ficus. Charlie grins.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: She got an Emmy nomination!  147.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: She’s a great actress.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: No, for directing! Charlie nods, a bit stunned.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I love it. Now I know what you were so obsessed with all the time. (moving) We should get ready! (to Charlie) We're the Beatles. Everyone clomps upstairs. Charlie follows.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I didn’t really get a costume together.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: You can be George Martin.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t need to be anything.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER NICOLE
dialogues.text: You got to be something-- At least a ghost! I'’11 get you a sheet-- Sandra and Carter hurry into different rooms, getting ready. Nicole enters into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We should leave soon! I’m saying that as much for me as anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I wanted to tell you, I took a residency at UCLA. I’m going to direct two plays in rep at Red Cat. Nicole reenters holding a sheet.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: So, I’1l be here for a while.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: That’s great. But something strikes her as sad about it too.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You OK?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Yeah. It’s only good. Sandra calls her for help with her costume. Nicole hands Charlie the sheet and goes into the next room. Charlie, alone, inspects the sheet. He notices the photos on the wall have been swapped out with different ones. He hears:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: “Charlie is...in...cr...” -- something -- "neat and I re-ly on him to keep things in or-der. He’s energy con...” -- I don’t know what that word is -- Charlie drifts towards Henry’s room. Henry, legs dangling off his bed, reads from a crinkled loose leaf paper.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You’re getting so good at reading. (beat) What is that?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: “He doesn’t look in the mirror too of-ten. He cries eas-ily in movies...” Charlie hesitates and sits next to Henry on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: “He is very self-suf--”

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Self-sufficient.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: “--he can dar-n a sock--"  149.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE HENRY
dialogues.text: That means sew, like a hole-- “--and cook himself dinner and ir--”

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Break it into two parts.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Ur. On.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Not “ur” but “ire”

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Ire. On.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Iron.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: “--a shirt. He rarely gets def- eated (which I fell...feel like I al-ways do). Charlie takes all of my moods stead-ily, he doesn’t give in to them or make me feel bad about them. He’s a great dress-er, he never looks em--” I don’t know this one...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Embarrassing. Nicole appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: “--embarrassing wh-ich is hard for aman.” You read it now... He hands it to Charlie. Charlie reads:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: “He loves being a dad, he loves all the things you’re supposed to hate, like the tantrums, the waking up at night-- He disappears into his own world. He and Henry are alike in that way. He can tell people they have food in their teeth or on their face in a way that doesn’t make them feel bad. Charlie is self-made -- his parents -- I only met them once -- but he told me there was-- (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Charlie skips ahead for Henry's benefit) He’s brilliant at creating family out of whoever is around. With the theatre company he cast a spell that made everyone feel included. No one, not even an intern was unimportant.”

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What’s an intern?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Like a helper. But who isn’t paid.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Why aren’t they paid?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: They’re young. They’re learning... I don’t know, maybe if they do a good job, they get paid later?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: OK. Keep going.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: “He could remember all the inside jokes. He’s extremely organized and thorough. He’s very clear about what he wants unlike me who can’t always tell. I fell in love with him two seconds after I saw him and I’1l never stop loving him...” Charlie hesitates. He swallows. He’s crying.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: “,..even though it doesn’t make sense anymore.”

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PASADENA RESIDENTIAL STREETS, LA, LATE DAY
dialogues.text: Henry, Nicole, Carter, Sandra are dressed as the Beatles from Sgt. Pepper. Carter is Paul. Henry is Ringo. Nicole is John. Sandra is George. Charlie’s a ghost. They’re joined by Cassie and Sam and their kids, also dressed up. The kids run from house to house trick-or-treating. The adults linger and talk casually.  151. Henry, exhausted, is having trouble keeping his eyes open Nicole regards him. Charlie, his sheet on his arm now, is saying goodbye to the family as Sandra takes off with Cassie and Sam. He shakes Carter’s hand, it’s friendly. Nicole hesitates then approaches Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: We were going to bring him to dinner, but he’s wiped out. Do you want to take him?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (taken aback) It’s your night...

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: OK, good.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE NICOLE
dialogues.text: I’1l drop him back in the Yeah, just text when you’re morning? up and we'll figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (leaning down to Henry) You’re going to go with your Dad,

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: The boy wraps his arms around his Dad’s neck and Charlie lifts him.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I love you, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I love you. She kisses Henry’s face which rests on Charlie’s shoulder and for a moment all three of their heads are nestled clo together. Then Nicole releases. Charlie, holding Henry, advances toward his parked car. Nicole watches.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Wait--  152. Charlie hesitates as Nicole hurries after him. She kneels down in the middle of the street. CLOSE: Charlie’s laces spill out on the pavement. She tugs on one which he’s stepping on. She taps his calf

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Can you-- He lifts up his foot so she can retrieve the lace. She ties his sneaker. Charlie watches.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (smiles) Thanks. She nods. He hikes Henry up tighter in his arms and continues toward his car. Nicole and Carter get in their parked Subaru in the foreground. The Subaru drives toward us and off-camera and then reapp heading away from us now. As they pass Charlie and Henry, arm waves out the window. Charlie raises his hand back. Nicole's car heads into the distance. Charlie stops at hi rental and digs for the keys in his pocket. Henry holds o All of them, Nicole and Charlie and Henry, are now recess into the landscape. The light is waning. We hold on the wide tableau of the LA street and finally cut to black. End.
